• The issue in this case was whether the defendant was liable for the damage caused by the fire.
• The claimant argued that the defendant was negligent in allowing the oil to leak into the harbor, which caused the fire.
• The defendant argued that the fire was not foreseeable, and thus they should not be held liable for the damages.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the defendant was not liable for the damage.
• The court applied the test of foreseeability, established in Donoghue v Stevenson [1932] UKHL 100, and found that the defendant could not have reasonably foreseen that their negligence would lead to the fire and consequent damages.
• In reaching this decision, the court also overruled the case of Re Polemis & Furness Withy & Co Ltd [1921] 3 KB 560, which held that once negligence was established, a defendant would be liable for all direct consequences of their actions, regardless of whether the consequences were foreseeable.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is not the act but the consequences on which tortious liability is founded. ... Who knows or can be assumed to know all the processes of nature? But if it would be wrong that a man should be held liable for damage unpredictable by a reasonable man because it was 'direct' or 'natural,' equally it would be wrong that he should escape liability, however 'indirect' the damage, if he foresaw or could reasonably foresee the intervening events which led to its being done.' (Viscount Simonds)

cases.name: Page v Smith [1996] AC 155
cases.summary:
Facts
• Page sustained a depressive illness as a result of the 1988 accident when Smith lost control of his car which hit Page's vehicle.
• Page was suffering from myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME) at the time, but Smith was not aware of this.
• The depressive illness worsened Page's ME resulting in severe disability, and he claimed damages from Smith.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Smith was liable for Page's worsening ME condition resulting from the depressive illness.
• Smith argued that he should not be held liable as the ME was an unforeseeable consequence of the accident, and the psychiatric injury was a mere materialization of an existing disease.
• Page argued that his ME condition would not have worsened if not for the accident.

Decision
• The House of Lords held Smith liable for the worsening of Page's ME condition as a result of the injury sustained in the accident.
• The Lords applied the eggshell skull rule and reasoned that finding liability did not depend on whether the consequences were foreseeable or not.
• The Lords also referred to the case of Bourhill v Young [1943] AC 92, where no duty of care arose regarding unforeseen psychiatric harm.
• However, in this case, a duty of care existed as the physical injury caused by Smith's negligence worsened Page's ME condition.

cases.name: Smith v Leech Brain & Co Ltd [1962] 2 QB 405
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Smith v Leech Brain & Co Ltd [1962] 2 QB 405, the claimant, Mr. Smith, worked in the defendant's factory.
• An accident occurred whereby the claimant was splashed with a small amount of molten metal.
• The metal burned Mr. Smith's lip, leading to the development of cancer and his subsequent death.
• The claimant's widow brought an action for damages.

Issues
• The key issue in the case was whether the defendant could be held liable for Mr. Smith's death.
• The defendant argued that his death resulted from an unforeseeable consequence of the accident, and therefore they should not be held liable.
• Conversely, the claimant's widow argued that the defendant was liable as they had breached their duty of care by allowing the accident to happen.

Decision
• The court held that the defendants were liable for Mr. Smith's death.
• The court applied the principle established in Hughes v Lord Advocate [1963] AC 837, which stated that if the injury was foreseeable, the defendant would be liable for the entire consequences of their actions, even if the extent of the harm was not foreseeable.
• In this case, it was foreseeable that the claimant could suffer burn injuries from the molten metal.
• Thus, the defendant was held liable for the full extent of the harm caused to the claimant.

Key passage(s)
• 'If a man is negligently run over... it is no answer to the sufferer’s claim for damages that he would have suffered less injury... if he had not had an unusually thin skull or an unusually weak heart' (Lord Parker).

cases.name: Cambridge Water Co Ltd v Eastern Counties Leather plc [1994] 2 AC 264
cases.summary:
Facts
• Cambridge Water Co Ltd (Cambridge Water) provided water to customers and owned a nearby borehole.
• Eastern Counties Leather plc (ECL) owned a tannery that contaminated the borehole's groundwater with solvents.
• The chemicals were found to be too high for consumption, rendering the borehole unusable.
• Cambridge Water sued ECL for the loss of their water supply.

Issues
• Whether ECL should be held liable for negligently causing contamination to the groundwater.
• The foreseeability of the harm caused.
• ECL's argument that they should not be held liable due to the unknown long-term effects of the chemicals used, and lack of knowledge that the chemicals would contaminate the borehole.
• Cambridge Water's argument that ECL should be held liable for the contamination, as they were negligent in disposing the chemicals.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that ECL was not liable for Cambridge Water's losses due to the contamination of the borehole.
• The court found that the harmful effects of the contaminants were not reasonably foreseeable by ECL, as neither party knew, or should have known, about the harmful relationship between the chemicals and groundwater.
• Additionally, the court held that a reasonable person in ECL's position would not have taken any additional precautions in disposing of the chemicals.
• The court applied the 'reasonable foreseeability of harm' test from Rylands v Fletcher (1868) LR 3 HL 330, stating that foreseeability was a significant factor in determining ECL’s responsibility.

cases.name: Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire [1989] AC 53
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1980, Jacqueline Hill was the 13th victim of the notorious 'Yorkshire Ripper,' Peter Sutcliffe.
• The police investigation had been severely criticized for its handling of the case, including failure to arrest Sutcliffe earlier.
• Hill's mother sued West Yorkshire's Chief Constable, alleging negligence and seeking damages.
• The case ultimately reached the House of Lords in 1989.

Issues
• The central issue was whether the police owed a duty of care to individual members of the public, specifically to potential victims of serial killers.
• The plaintiff argued that the police were negligent in their investigation and breached their duty, leading to the death of Ms. Hill.
• Conversely, the defendant contended that there was no duty of care owed to individual members of the public in relation to the detection and prevention of crimes.

Decision
• The House of Lords ruled in favor of the defendant, holding that the police do not owe a duty of care to individual members of the public in relation to the investigation and prevention of crime.
• This was based on public policy considerations, including the risk that imposing such a duty would divert police resources and impede effective law enforcement.
• The Court also relied on the precedent set in Anns v Merton London Borough Council [1978] AC 728, which established a two-stage test for determining whether a duty of care exists.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is plain that vital characteristics which were present in the Dorset Yacht case and which led to the imposition of liability are here lacking. Sutcliffe was never in the custody of the police force. Miss Hill was one of a vast number of the female general public who might be at risk from his activities but was at no special distinctive risk in relation to them. ... That is sufficient for the disposal of the appeal. But in my opinion there is another reason why an action for damages in negligence should not lie against the police in circumstances such as those of the present case, and that is public policy.' (Lord Keith at 62)

cases.name: Murphy v Brentwood District Council [1991] 1 AC 398
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, Mr. Murphy, purchased a house from Brentwood District Council, the defendants.
• Drainage works related to the house were not properly constructed, causing the house to be damaged and unsafe for habitation.
• Mr. Murphy sued the council for the cost of repairing the house and won in the lower courts, relying on the principle of negligence established in Anns v Merton London Borough Council (1978).

Issues
• The council argued that it did not owe a duty of care to Mr. Murphy, as any loss was purely economic.
• Mr. Murphy claimed that the council owed a duty of care in construction resulting in physical damage to the house.

Decision
• The House of Lords unanimously overturned the lower courts' decisions.
• They held that the damage was purely economic rather than physical, as the house itself was not damaged but rather reduced in value due to the negligent construction.
• In doing so, the House of Lords overruled the Anns case, holding that the local authority does not owe a duty of care to protect against purely economic loss arising from construction defects.

Key passage(s)
• 'My Lords, I would hold that Anns was wrongly decided as regards the scope of any private law duty of care resting upon local authorities in relation to their function of taking steps to secure compliance with building byelaws or regulations and should be departed from. It follows that Dutton v. Bognor Regis Urban District Council [1972] 1 Q.B. 373 should be overruled, as should all cases subsequent to Anns which were decided in reliance on it.' (Lord Keith)

cases.name: Watson v British Boxing Board of Control [2001] QB 1134
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, Michael Watson, a professional boxer, sustained severe brain damage during a world title fight against Chris Eubank.
• The British Boxing Board of Control (BBBC) was the body responsible for regulating the sport, including the safety measures enforced during fights.
• Watson argued that the BBBC was in breach of the duty of care that they owed him as a participant, and he sought damages for personal injury.

Issues
• Watson's legal team argued that the BBBC owed a duty of care to ensure his safety, which was breached by inadequate safety regulations such as the lack of medical staff present at the event, as well as the absence of proper procedures to manage head injuries during the fight.
• The BBBC denied that such a duty of care existed, and contended that Watson voluntarily participated in a dangerous sport and thus assumed the risk of injury.

Decision
• The court held that the BBBC did indeed owe a duty of care to Watson, and was in breach of this duty because of its inadequate safety measures.
• Watson was awarded damages for his injuries.
• The court established that governing bodies of sports can be held liable for breaching their duty of care to participants if they fail to take reasonable steps to ensure safety.

cases.name: R v Dudley and Stephens (1884) 14 QBD 273 DC
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1884, four men, including Thomas Dudley and Edwin Stephens, were stranded at sea for 20 days after their yacht sank.
• They were without food or water for several days and became delirious.
• In their desperation, Dudley and Stephens killed and ate the cabin boy, Richard Parker, who was 17 years old.
• Upon their rescue, they were charged with murder.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the men were guilty of murder or if they could rely on the defence of necessity.
• The defence argued that they had acted out of necessity to save their own lives, and that the boy would have died anyway.
• The prosecution argued that the men had committed murder and that there was no defence for their actions.

Decision
• The court held that the men were guilty of murder and rejected the defence of necessity.
• The judges stated that there was no absolute rule that the preservation of a person's own life justified taking the life of an innocent person.
• The court emphasized the importance of the sanctity of human life and the need to maintain social order, even in extreme circumstances.

Key passage(s)
• 'Now it is admitted that the deliberate killing of this unoffending and unresisting boy was clearly murder, unless the killing can be justified by some well-recognised excuse admitted by the law. It is further admitted that there was in this case no such excuse, unless the killing was justified by what has been called 'necessity'. But the temptation to the act which existed here was not what the law has ever called necessity. Nor is this to be regretted.' (Lord Coleridge CJ)
• 'It is not needful to point out the awful danger of admitting the principle which has been contended for. Who is to be the judge of this sort of necessity? By what measure is the comparative value of lives to be measured? Is it to be strength, or intellect or what? It is plain that the principle leaves to him who is to profit by it to determine the necessity which will justify him in deliberately taking another's life to save his own. In this case the weakest, the youngest, the most unresisting, was chosen. Was it more necessary to kill him than one of the grown men? The answer must be 'No'. (Lord Coleridge CJ)

cases.name: R v R [1992] 1 AC 599, HL
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1991, a husband and wife separated but were not yet divorced.
• The husband raped his wife against her will after they separated.
• The husband was charged with rape.
• Before this case, it was widely accepted that a husband could not be charged with raping his wife ('marital rape exemption').

Issues
• The prosecution argued that the marital rape exemption should no longer exist in law, as it is outdated and contrary to modern society's recognition of equal rights for women.
• The defence argued that the marital rape exemption is a well-established principle and should continue to apply.

Decision
• The House of Lords (HL) decided that the marital rape exemption should no longer apply.
• The husband was found guilty of rape, and the decision effectively abolished the marital rape exemption in English law.
• There was no need to wait for Parliament to legislate changes.

Key passage(s)
'The common law is, however, capable of evolving in the light of changing social, economic and cultural developments. … one of the most important changes is that marriage is in modern times regarded as a partnership of equals, and no longer one in which the wife must be the subservient chattel of the husband. [Matthew] Hale's proposition involves that by marriage a wife gives her irrevocable consent to sexual intercourse with her husband under all circumstances and irrespective of the state of her health or how she happens to be feeling at the time. In modern times any reasonable person must regard that conception as quite unacceptable.' (Lord Keith)

cases.name: R v Gnango [2011] UKSC 59
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Gnango [2011] UKSC 59, the appellant, Gnango, was involved in a shootout with another man known as 'Bandana Man'.
• Both fired guns at each other in a public place, however neither of them was harmed.
• While Bandana Man was aiming at Gnango, a stray bullet struck and killed an innocent bystander.
• Gnango was subsequently charged and convicted with murder based on the doctrine of joint enterprise.
• He appealed, arguing that the trial judge failed to properly direct the jury on the issue of joint enterprise, which resulted in his conviction.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Gnango could be held liable for the murder, even though he did not directly cause the death of the bystander.
• The prosecution argued that both men were engaged in a criminal enterprise, namely a gunfight, which resulted in the murder, and therefore both were liable for the crime.
• The defence argued that Gnango could not be held liable as he was neither the principal offender nor had the intention to assist or encourage Bandana Man in committing the murder.

Decision
• The Supreme Court, in a 5-2 majority, upheld Gnango's conviction for murder.
• The Court found that both participants in the criminal joint enterprise, assuming that each intended to kill or cause serious harm, could be held liable for the murder that arose from the execution of that enterprise.
• The Court also rejected the argument that jury's verdict was inconsistent, finding that the joint enterprise requirement of necessary foresight had been satisfied in Gnango's case.

Key passage(s)
• '[i]t is artificial to treat the intention to have an affray as a separate intention from the intention to have a potentially homicidal shooting match.' (Lord Judge at para 43).
• 'there is no common law rule that precludes conviction of a defendant of being party to a crime of which he was the actual or intended victim' (Lord Judge at para 52).

cases.name: R v Brown [1994] 1 AC 212
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Brown, a group of five participants engaged in consensual sado-masochistic acts, causing each other varying degrees of physical harm.
• The acts included beatings, brandings, and genital torture, but the participants had all willingly consented to the harm.
• They were convicted under the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 (OAPA) for assault occasioning actual bodily harm (ABH) and unlawful wounding.
• The defendants appealed, arguing that consent was a valid defence.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the defendants' consent to the harm could serve as a valid defence to the charges under the OAPA.
• The defendants argued that because the acts were conducted in private, between consenting adults, and without any lasting harm, consent should be a valid defence.
• The prosecution argued that, considering the serious nature of the inflicted harm, public policy required that consent be invalid as a defence.

Decision
• The House of Lords upheld the convictions, ruling that consent was not a valid defence to ABH and unlawful wounding in these circumstances.
• The judges held that, even though the acts were consensual, the public policy concerns regarding violent and dangerous behaviour prevailed over the interests of individual privacy and autonomy.
• The court referred to R v Donovan (1934) and R v Wilson (1996), finding that, previously, consent had not been considered a valid defence in cases involving such serious harm.

Key passage(s)
• 'Society is entitled and bound to protect itself against a cult of violence. Pleasure derived from the infliction of pain is an evil thing. Cruelty is uncivilised.' (Lord Templeman)
• 'Sado-masochistic homosexual activity cannot be regarded as conducive to the enhancement or enjoyment of family life or conducive to the welfare of society.' (Lord Lowry)

cases.name: R v Woolin [1999] 1 AC 82, HL
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Mr. Woolin, threw his three-month-old son across the room, who consequently suffered a fatal head injury.
• Woolin was charged with murder and the trial judge directed the jury using the test for oblique intention provided in R v Nedrick [1986] 3 All ER 1 (the defendant should foresee that the prohibited result is 'virtually certain' to occur).
• Woolin was convicted of murder, but the Court of Appeal reduced the conviction to manslaughter.
• The Crown appealed this decision to the House of Lords.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the Nedrick test for oblique intention was correct in directing juries in cases of murder where direct intent could not be proven.
• The Crown argued that the test was correct and that Woolin's conviction for murder should be reinstated.
• Woolin argued that the test was not correct and that his conviction for manslaughter should stand.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the Nedrick test should not be regarded as a separate test for intent, but rather a clarification of the ordinary meaning of intention.
• It was decided that a jury should find intention if satisfied that the defendant foresaw death or serious bodily harm as a 'virtual certainty' but that foreseeing a result is not the same as intending it.
• The Lords dismissed the Crown's appeal and upheld Woolin's conviction for manslaughter.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where the charge is murder and in the rare cases where the simple direction is not enough, the jury should be directed that they are not entitled to infer the necessary intention, unless they feel sure that death or serious bodily harm was a virtual certainty (barring some unforeseen intervention) as a result of the defendant's actions and that the defendant appreciated that such was the case.' (Lord Steyn)

cases.name: R v Ireland and Burstow [1998] AC 147
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Ireland and R v Burstow were two separate cases that were heard together by the House of Lords (HL).
• Ireland was accused of making silent phone calls to three women, causing them psychological harm.
• Burstow stalked a woman and engaged in acts such as making harassing phone calls, entering her home without permission, and sending her offensive mail.
• Both women suffered from psychological harm as a result of their respective ordeals, with the victim of Burstow developing clinical depression.

Issues
• The issue was whether in the offences of assault occasioning actual bodily harm (ABH) under the s47 Offences Against the Person Act 1861 and malicious wounding or infliction of grievous bodily harm (GBH) under the s20 Offences Against the Person Act 1861, 'bodily harm' could include psychological harm.
• The defendants argued that only physical harm should be considered 'bodily harm'.
• The prosecution argued that psychological harm should be included within the definition of 'bodily harm'.

Decision
• The HL, in a unanimous decision, held that 'bodily harm' could include psychological harm.
• The convictions for Ireland and Burstow were upheld.
• The Lords distinguished R v Donovan [1934] 2 KB 498, ruling that Donovan's reasoning that 'bodily harm' was limited to physical harm could not stand.

Key passage(s)
• 'The proposition that a gesture may amount to an assault, but that words can never suffice, is unrealistic and indefensible. A thing said is also a thing done. There is no reason why something said should be incapable of causing an apprehension of immediate personal violence...' (Lord Steyn)

cases.name: DPP v Majewski [1977] AC 443
cases.summary:
Facts
• DPP v Majewski [1977] AC 443 (House of Lords) is an English criminal law case concerning the defence of intoxication.
• The defendant, Majewski, had consumed a large quantity of drugs and alcohol in the days preceding the incident.
• As a result, he violently assaulted several individuals, including police officers.
• He was charged with various offences including assault and battery as well as causing grievous bodily harm.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether Majewski's intoxicated state could be a defence to the crimes he committed.
• The defence argued that his intoxication rendered him incapable of forming the necessary mens rea (intention or knowledge) for the offences.
• The prosecution argued that his voluntary intoxication should not be a defence, as the law should not reward those who deliberately put themselves in a state where they are likely to commit crimes.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that voluntary intoxication could not be a defence to basic intent crimes, which included the offences Majewski was charged with.
• Voluntary intoxication could only be a defence to specific intent crimes, where the defendant must have intended the specific consequences of his actions.
• The court reasoned that public policy required the law to deter individuals from intentionally putting themselves in a position where they are more likely to commit crimes due to intoxication.

Key passage(s)
'If a man of his own volition takes a substance which causes him to cast off the restraints of reason and conscience, no wrong is done to him by holding him answerable criminally for any injury he may do while in that condition. His course of conduct in reducing himself by drugs and drink to that condition in my view supplies the evidence of mens rea, of guilty mind certainly sufficient for crimes of basic intent. It is a reckless course of conduct and recklessness is enough to constitute the necessary mens rea in assault cases. … The drunkenness is itself an intrinsic, an integral part of the crime, the other part being the evidence of the unlawful use of force against the victim. Together they add up to criminal recklessness.' - (Lord Elwyn-Jones)

cases.name: R v Blaue [1975] 1 WLR 1411
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Blaue, was convicted of murdering a Jehovah's Witness.
• The victim was stabbed by the appellant but she could have survived if she had accepted a blood transfusion treatment.
• Due to her religious beliefs, she refused the blood transfusion, thus leading to her death.

Issues
• The appellant argued that he should not be held responsible for the victim's death, as it was her own refusal to accept the blood transfusion which led to her death.
• The prosecution held that the appellant's conduct was the direct cause of the victim's death, as it was a reasonably foreseeable event that would not have occurred without the appellant's actions.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appellant's arguments, upholding his conviction for murder.
• The Court held that the defendant must take the victim as he finds her, even if the victim's religious beliefs played a part in her death.
• The Court held that it was the defendant's actions that put the victim in the position where she needed medical treatment, and there was no break in the chain of causation.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Justice Lawton: 'those who use violence on others must take their victims as they find them,'

cases.name: R v Savage; DPP v Parmenter [1992] 1 AC 699
cases.summary:
Facts
• In two separate cases, the defendants, Savage and Parmenter, were charged with causing grievous bodily harm (GBH) under the Offences Against the Person Act 1861.
• Savage threw a glass at her husband's ex-girlfriend, resulting in injury to her face.
• Parmenter caused injuries to his four-month-old son by mishandling him.
• Both defendants claimed that they had not intended to cause serious injury.

Issues
• The cases required the House of Lords (HL) to consider whether the defendants' lack of intention to cause GBH was a valid defence for the charges brought under the Act, and whether recklessness was sufficient as an element of mens rea for section 20 (s 20).
• Savage's counsel argued that the offence requires specific intent to cause GBH.
• Parmenter's counsel argued that causing injury was not 'wicked' or 'reckless' as there was no risk-taking behaviour in his actions.

Decision
• The HL held that neither Savage nor Parmenter had to intend to cause GBH for their actions to be criminal under s 20.
• It was sufficient for the defendants to have foreseen that some harm might result from their actions.
• A distinction was drawn between s 18 and s 20 of the Act.
• Section 18 requires specific intent to cause GBH, whereas s 20 only requires recklessness.
• Savage's conviction under s 20 was upheld.
• Parmenter's conviction under s 20 was also upheld.

cases.name: R v Mohan [1976] QB 1
cases.summary:
Facts:
• The appellant, Mr. Mohan, was convicted of dangerous driving in violation of s2 (1) of the Road Traffic Act 1972.
• The incident involved a high-speed chase between the appellant's car and police vehicles.
• The appellant contested the charge and argued that his driving was not dangerous but only reckless.

Issues:
• The main legal issue was the interpretation of 'dangerous driving' and whether the appellant's driving met the legal standard.
• The appellant argued that there was a distinction between dangerous and reckless driving and that his driving fell within the latter category.
• The prosecution contended that the appellant's driving posed a significant risk to public safety, therefore constituting dangerous driving.

Decision:
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, upholding the conviction.
• The Court held that ‘dangerous driving’ is based on an objective test that considers whether the driving in question falls far below the standard expected of a competent and careful driver.
• It was determined that the appellant’s conduct during the high-speed chase clearly met this standard.

cases.name: R v Moloney [1985] 1 AC 905
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant and his stepfather had a competition to see who could load and fire a shotgun the fastest.
• The appellant believed the gun to be empty, but it was loaded and he accidentally shot and killed his stepfather.
• The appellant was convicted of murder and appealed the conviction on the grounds that the trial judge had misdirected the jury on the issue of mens rea (intention) for murder.

Issues
• The main issue in the appeal was whether the trial judge had properly directed the jury on the mens rea for murder.
• The appellant argued that the judge's direction on intention was incorrect and resulted in an unfair conviction.
• The respondent maintained that the judge's direction was a correct statement of the law and that the jury was entitled to find the necessary intention for murder based on the facts presented.

Decision
• The House of Lords allowed the appeal and quashed the murder conviction, substituting it with one for manslaughter.
• The court concluded that the trial judge's direction on intention was not in accordance with the principles set down in R v. Hyam [1975] AC 55 and was therefore inadequate.
• The House of Lords laid down guidelines on the correct test for intention in murder cases in common law, which included a distinction between foresight of consequences and intention as the two aspects of mens rea.

Key passage(s)
• 'The golden rule should be that, when directing a jury on the mental element necessary in a crime of specific intent, the judge should avoid any elaboration or paraphrase of what is meant by intent, and leave it to the jury's good sense to decide whether the accused acted with the necessary intent, unless the judge is convinced that, on the facts and having regard to the way the case has been presented to the jury in evidence and argument, some further explanation or elaboration is strictly necessary to avoid misunderstanding.' - (Lord Bridge)
• 'In the rare cases in which it is necessary to direct a jury by reference to foresight of consequences, I do not believe it is necessary for the judge to do more than invite the jury to consider two questions. First, was death or really serious injury in a murder case (or whatever relevant consequence must be proved to have been intended in any other case) a natural consequence of the defendant's voluntary act? Secondly, did the defendant foresee that consequence as being a natural consequence of his act? The jury should then be told that if they answer yes to both questions it is a proper inference for them to draw that he intended that consequence.' - (Lord Bridge)

cases.name: R v Nedrick [1986] 1 WLR 1025
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Alwyn Nedrick, was convicted of murder after starting a fire at the home of the victim, which led to her death.
• The appellant claimed that the fire was only intended to frighten the victim and her partner.

Issues
• The appellant argued that the crime he committed was arson, not murder.
• The prosecution held that the appellant's conduct in setting the fire constituted the essential elements of murder – a mens rea (guilty mind) and an actus reus (guilty act) – given that he should have foreseen the risk of death from his actions.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal ruled that there was a lack of sufficient mens rea to convict the appellant for murder as the appellant did not intend to kill or cause grievous bodily harm to the victim.
• The Court held that, for a murder conviction, the mens rea requirement is only satisfied if the defendant was virtually certain of the victim's death or grievous bodily harm as a result of their actions.
• The Court found that the appellant did not meet this requirement and reduced his conviction to attempted arson and manslaughter.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Justice Lane: 'the jury should be directed that they are not entitled to infer the necessary intention, unless they feel sure that death or serious bodily harm was a virtual certainty (barring some unforeseen intervention) as a result of the defendant's actions and that the defendant appreciated that such was the case.'

cases.name: R v Hancock and Shankland [1986] AC 455
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellants, Hancock and Shankland, were two striking miners involved in the 1984-85 miners' strike in the UK.
• They dropped a concrete block from a bridge onto a taxi carrying a non-striking miner to work, killing the taxi driver.
• Both were charged with murder and appealed to the House of Lords (HL) against their convictions on the grounds that the trial judge misdirected the jury on the issue of intention to cause grievous bodily harm (GBH).

Issues
• The issue before the HL was whether the trial judge had adequately instructed the jury regarding the concept and requirement of intention for a murder conviction.
• The appellants argued that the jury should have been directed to consider the probability that their actions would cause death or GBH, not the mere possibility, in determining their intention.

Decision
• The HL allowed the appeal and quashed the murder convictions.
• They held that the jury had been misdirected in their interpretation of what constitutes intent.
• Lord Scarman established that the jury should consider the degree of probability of death or GBH occurring and that a higher degree of probability would suggest the necessary intent for murder.
• The case was influential in clarifying the concept of intention for murder, establishing a more practical approach to determining a defendant's mens rea for the crime.

cases.name: R v Matthews and Alleyne [2003] EWCA Crim 192
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Matthews and Alleyne [2003] EWCA Crim 192 concerned the criminal responsibility for unplanned, subsequent acts since Rogers ('R') in R v Rogers [2003] EWCA Crim 611 previously did not establish any legal principle.
• Matthews and Alleyne ('Defendants') had confessed that they were involved in an unplanned theft, and they had scrambled over walls and dropped from a railway bridge.
• A railway employee, Nicholas Reddin, had chased them onto the bridge, but tragically drowned after falling into a river.
• Defendants were convicted of manslaughter and appealed to the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the defendants could be held criminally responsible for the death of Mr. Reddin, since there was no intention to harm, nor any act or omission that directly led to his death.
• The defendants appealed on the basis that their case did not satisfy the requirements of causation and legal proximity.
• The prosecution argued that the defendants' actions of theft and subsequent chase provided sufficient grounds for criminal responsibility for manslaughter.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the defendants' appeals and upheld the convictions for manslaughter.
• The court held that the defendants brought about a dangerous situation causing Mr. Reddin to chase them as a result of their actions.
• The causal link between the defendants' actions and Mr. Reddin's death was not weakened by the fact that they did not actively encourage or foresee the chase.

cases.name: Bolton v Mahadeva [1972] 1 WLR 1009
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, Bolton, was a central heating contractor who installed a central heating system in the defendant, Mahadeva's house.
• The defendant agreed to pay £560 but shortly after the work was completed, numerous defects were discovered and the system malfunctioned.
• The defendant refused to pay the full amount and the plaintiff issued a claim for the unpaid sum.

Issues
• The plaintiff argued that they had substantially performed their duties under the contract and therefore were entitled to payment.
• The defendant argued that the performance was so defective that it amounted to non-performance or a total failure of consideration.

Decision
• The court held in favour of the defendant, finding that the performance was so poor that it amounted to a total failure of consideration.
• The court applied the principle from Hoenig v. Isaacs [1952] 2 All ER 176, where it was held that incomplete or defective performance will not amount to a total failure of consideration unless the defects are so substantial as to make the performance virtually worthless.
• The court found that the plaintiff's performance was virtually worthless, as the defendant had to spend an almost equivalent amount to rectify the defects.' Megaw LJ

cases.name: Bruton v. London and Quadrant Housing Trust [1999] UKHL 26; [2000] 1 AC 406; [1999] 3 All ER 481
cases.summary:
Facts
• The London and Quadrant Housing Trust provided Mr Bruton with temporary accommodation under a so-called 'licence' as they themselves only held a licence from the Lambeth Borough Council.
• Mr Bruton sought to hold the Trust accountable for the statutorily implied repairing obligations under section 11 of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1985.

Issues
• The Trust contended that given it only held a licence from the council and had granted Bruton the same, the agreement didn't constitute a tenancy.
• Mr Bruton argued that despite the 'licence' description, the agreement effectively granted an exclusive possession, hence creating a tenancy.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that despite being framed as a 'licence', the agreement bestowed exclusive possession, and hence amounted to a tenancy.
• Therefore, the statutory repairing obligations applied to the Trust.

Key passage(s)
• 'The term 'lease' or 'tenancy' describes a relationship between two parties who are designated landlord and tenant. It is not concerned with the question of whether the agreement creates an estate or other proprietary interest which may be binding upon third parties. A lease may, and usually does, create a proprietary interest called a leasehold estate or, technically, a 'term of years absolute.' This will depend upon whether the landlord had an interest out of which he could grant it. Nemo dat quod non habet. But it is the fact that the agreement is a lease which creates the proprietary interest. It is putting the cart before the horse to say that whether the agreement is a lease depends upon whether it creates a proprietary interest.' - Lord Hoffmann

cases.name: City of London Building Society v Flegg [1987] UKHL 6, [1988] AC 54
cases.summary:
Facts
• In City of London Building Society v Flegg [1988] AC 54, the respondents, Mr. and Mrs. Flegg, granted a mortgage to City of London Building Society (City) on a property. The mortgage was not registered, and later the property was sold to a third party, Mr. and Mrs. Gould. The Fleggs paid the mortgage proceeds to the Goulds, effectively charging the Goulds' interest in the property.
• The Fleggs also executed a promissory note that allowed City to demand payment from the Goulds.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the mortgage granted by the Fleggs to City had priority over the interest of the Goulds in the property, or whether the Goulds' interest in the property took priority over City's mortgage interest.
• City argued that the mortgage had priority over the Goulds' interest due to the doctrine of overreaching, as per the Law of Property Act 1925, s.27(2) (LPA).
• The Goulds contended that the mortgage was not registered and, as such, it did not have priority over their interest in the property.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that City's mortgage interest took priority over the Goulds' interest in the property due to the doctrine of overreaching. Because of this, the mortgage debt followed the proceeds, and the Goulds' interest was charged with the mortgage debt

Key passage(s)
• 'One of the main objects of the legislation of 1925 was to effect a compromise between on the one hand the interests of the public in securing that land held in trust is freely marketable and, on the other hand, the interests of the beneficiaries in preserving their rights under the trusts. By the Settled Land Act 1925 a tenant for life may convey the settled land discharged from all the trusts powers and provisions of the settlement. By the Law of Property Act 1925 trustees for sale may convey land held on trust for sale discharged from the trusts affecting the proceeds of sale and rents and profits until sale. Under both forms of trust the protection and the only protection of the beneficiaries is that capital money must be paid to at least two trustees or a trust corporation.' (Lord Templeman).

cases.name: Cobbe v Yeoman's Row Management Ltd [2008] UKHL 55
cases.summary:
Facts
• Cobbe and Yeoman's Row Management Ltd entered into an oral agreement for the development of a property.
• Cobbe agreed to obtain planning permission and pay for the costs of preparing the site, while Yeoman's Row agreed to sell the property to Cobbe to redevelop at a specified price.
• Cobbe invested significant resources into obtaining planning permission and preparing the site for development.
• Yeoman's Row subsequently refused to enter into a formal contract for the sale of the property in breach of the oral agreement.
• Cobbe brought a claim for proprietary estoppel, breach of contract, and unjust enrichment.

Issues
• Cobbe argued that he was entitled to relief based on proprietary estoppel due to the oral agreement and his reliance on it.
• Yeoman's Row argued that the agreement was not sufficiently certain to give rise to proprietary estoppel and that Cobbe should not have relied on it without formalizing a contract.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the oral agreement was not sufficiently certain to give rise to proprietary estoppel.
• The court noted that there was no assurance of a legally enforceable right in relation to the property, and therefore, Cobbe's reliance on the oral agreement was unreasonable.
• The House of Lords also rejected the claims for breach of contract and unjust enrichment.

cases.name: Etridge (No.2) [2002] 2 AC 773
cases.summary:
Facts
• Etridge (No.2) [2002] 2 AC 773 is a conjoined appeal of eight cases related to bank lending.
• In each case, a bank made a loan to a husband for his business.
• The wife agreed to stand as a surety for the loans, providing a charge on the family home.
• The husbands either misappropriated the loan funds or provided false information to the bank.
• The wives were largely uninvolved in the businesses and claimed they had not understood the implications of their guarantees.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the banks could enforce the guarantees and charges against the wives.
• The banks argued that they were entitled to enforce the guarantees and charges as the wives had given their consent.
• The wives asserted that their consent had not been truly given, as they had been misled by their husbands or acted under undue influence.
• The courts needed to determine the extent to which banks should be expected to make inquiries in situations of possible undue influence or misrepresentation.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that banks could not enforce the guarantees and charges in most of the cases.
• It was ruled that when a spouse gives a guarantee for the other spouse's debts, there is a presumption of undue influence.
• To rebut the presumption, the solicitor must provide independent advice to the spouse providing the guarantee.
• If a bank is aware of the potential undue influence or misrepresentation, it has a duty to ensure that the spouse receives independent advice.
• Failure to ensure the spouse receives independent advice renders the transaction voidable.

Key passage(s)
• '...in relation to any guarantee by a wife of her husband's debts (or those of his company) the bank is put on enquiry and accordingly will have to respond unless it is to run the risk of finding that the guarantee and other security provided by the wife are unenforceable. If it becomes aware of any aggravation of the risk of undue influence, its response must take that into account.' (Lord Hobhouse at para 110)

cases.name: Carlill v Carbolic Smoke Ball Company [1893] 1 QB 256
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Mrs. Carlill, purchased a Carbolic Smoke Ball, which was advertised by the defendant, the Carbolic Smoke Ball Company, as a remedy for various ailments.
• The advertisement contained an offer to pay £100 to anyone who contracted an illness after using the product according to the instructions.
• Mrs. Carlill used the product as directed but still contracted the flu and sought to claim the £100 reward.

Issues
• The company argued that the advertisement did not constitute a legally binding contract, as it was too vague and there was no intention to create legal relations.
• Mrs. Carlill argued that the advertisement constituted a valid offer, which she had accepted by her actions of purchasing and using the product.

Decision
• The court held that the advertisement constituted a unilateral contract, which was triggered by performance, and upheld Mrs. Carlill's claim.
• The court found that the advertisement contained a specific offer that was capable of being accepted by anyone who used the product as instructed and fell ill.
• The court also found that there was sufficient consideration to support the contract, as the use of the product constituted the detriment required.

Key passage(s)
• 'Was it intended that the £100 should, if the conditions were fulfilled, be paid? The advertisement says that 1000l. is lodged at the bank for the purpose. Therefore, it cannot be said that the statement that £100 would be paid was intended to be a mere puff. I think it was intended to be understood by the public as an offer which was to be acted upon.' (Bowen LJ)
• 'If this is an offer to be bound, then it is a contract the moment the person fulfils the condition.' (Bowen LJ)

cases.name: Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain v Boots Cash Chemists [1953] 1 QB 401
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1953, Boots Cash Chemists was a self-service pharmacy where customers self-selected the medicines and brought them to the cash register for payment.
• The Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain, responsible for regulating the sale of medicines, brought an action against Boots for illegally selling certain medicines which require supervision by a qualified pharmacist in contravention of the Pharmacy and Poisons Act 1933 (the Act).
• Boots argued that the contract for sale was made at the cash register, where a pharmacist was always present to supervise.

Issues
• The key issue in the case was whether the display of goods in a self-service store amounted to an offer by the store, which is accepted by the customer at the point of taking the goods from the shelf, or merely an invitation to treat, with the offer being made by the customer at the cash register.
• The Pharmaceutical Society argued that the display of the goods was an offer, meaning that the sales would be in breach of the Act.
• Boots argued that the display was merely an invitation to treat, and the actual offer and acceptance occurred at the cash register in the presence of a pharmacist, thus not in breach of the Act.

Decision
• The court held that the display of goods in a self-service store, like Boots, was an invitation to treat, not an offer.
• The contract of sale was made at the cash register, and since a pharmacist was present at all times to supervise the sales, Boots was not in breach of the Act.
• The court relied on the earlier case Partridge v Crittenden [1968] 1 WLR 1204, which held that advertisements, catalogues, and price lists were invitations to treat, not offers.

Key passage(s)
• '...in the case of the ordinary shop, although goods are displayed and it is intended that customers should go and choose what they want, the contract is not completed until, the customer having indicated the articles which he needs, the shop-keeper or someone on his behalf accepts that offer. Then the contract is completed.' (Lord Justice Somervell)

cases.name: Partridge v Crittenden [1968] 1 WLR 1204
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Partridge v Crittenden [1968] 1 WLR 1204, the defendant, Mr. Partridge, placed an advertisement in a magazine selling wild birds, namely bramblefinches.
• The advertisement read: 'Bramblefinch cocks and hens, 25s each.'
• Mr. Crittenden responded to the advertisement and purchased a bird.
• However, it was illegal to sell wild birds under the Protection of Birds Act 1954, thus Mr. Partridge was charged with unlawfully offering for sale wild birds.

Issues
• The issue in the case was whether the advertisement constituted an offer to sell the birds, which would make Mr. Partridge guilty of the offense.
• The prosecution argued that the advertisement was an offer due to its specific terms (price and bird type) and Mr. Partridge's intention to sell.
• In contrast, the defence contended that the advertisement was an invitation to treat, meaning it was merely a preliminary step toward making an offer or entering into negotiations.

Decision
• The court held that the advertisement was an invitation to treat, and not an offer.
• This decision was based on the principle that advertisements are generally considered invitations to treat, as established in cases like Carlill v Carbolic Smoke Ball Co [1893] 1 QB 256 and Fisher v Bell [1961] 1 QB 394.
• Consequently, Mr. Partridge was not guilty of unlawfully offering for sale wild birds, as no offer was made through the advertisement.

Key passage(s)
• '...I think when one is dealing with advertisements and circulars, unless they indeed come from manufacturers, there is business sense in their being construed as invitations to treat and not offers for sale.' (Lord Parker CJ)

cases.name: Fisher v Bell [1961] 1 QB 394
cases.summary:
Facts
• Fisher v Bell [1961] 1 QB 394 concerns the display of a flick knife in a shop window.
• The respondent, Mr. Bell, owned a shop that had a flick knife displayed in the window with a price tag attached.
• The appellant, as a police officer, brought proceedings against Mr. Bell under the Restriction of Offensive Weapons Act 1959 (the Act), which made it an offence to 'offer for sale' a flick knife.

Issues
• The appellant argued that by displaying the knife with a price tag, Mr. Bell was offering it for sale and therefore violating the Act.
• Mr. Bell argued that the display was not an offer but rather an invitation to treat (ITT), and therefore not an offence under the Act.
• The case turned on whether the display of the knife constituted an offer for sale under the Act or merely an ITT.

Decision
• The Queen's Bench Divisional Court (QBD) held that the display of the knife did not amount to an offer for sale under the Act.
• Instead, the QBD concluded that the display was an ITT, which is distinct from an offer for sale.
• The QBD drew on the principles established in Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain v Boots Cash Chemists (Southern) Ltd [1953] 1 QB 401, a case on the distinction between ITTs and offers for sale.
• Mr. Bell was therefore found not guilty of the offence.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is perfectly clear that according to the ordinary law of contract the display of an article with a price on it in a shop window is merely an invitation to treat. It is in no sense an offer for sale the acceptance of which constitutes a contract' (Lord Parker CJ)

cases.name: Smith v Hughes [1871] LR 6 QB 597
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Smith v Hughes (1871), the defendant (Hughes) agreed to purchase oats from the plaintiff (Smith).
• Smith sent a sample of the oats to Hughes.
• Hughes believed that the oats were old; however, they were actually new.
• Hughes did not want new oats and refused to pay for them.

Issues
• The issue in the case was whether there had been a mutual mistake of fact that would render the contract void.
• Smith argued that Hughes was bound to pay for the oats because the parties agreed on the price and the sample represented the oats that were to be delivered.
• Hughes countered that the contract should be void because there was a misunderstanding as to the quality of the oats, rendering the contract void for mistake.

Decision
• The court held that the contract was valid because the parties had agreed on the same terms, regardless of their individual beliefs about the quality of the oats.
• Therefore, Hughes was required to pay for the oats.

Key passage(s)
• 'If, whatever a man’s real intention may be, he so conducts himself that a reasonable man would believe that he was assenting to the terms proposed by the other party, and that other party upon that belief enters into the contract with him, the man thus conducting himself would be equally bound as if he had intended to agree to the other party’s terms.' (Blackburn J.)

cases.name: Entores Ltd v Miles Far East Corporation [1955] EWCA Civ 3, [1955] 2 QB 327
cases.summary:
Facts
• Entores, an English company, sent a telex message from London offering to purchase goods from Miles Far East Corporation, a company operating in Amsterdam.
• Miles Far East Corporation communicated acceptance of the offer via a telex message sent to London.

Issues
• The key issue in this case was determining where the contract between the parties was formed, as this would dictate which jurisdiction's law would govern the contract.
• Entores argued that the contract was formed in London, and therefore English law would apply, whereas Miles Far East Corporation contended that the acceptance was sent from Amsterdam, meaning Dutch law would be applicable.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the contract was formed in London (where the acceptance was received) and, therefore, English law would govern the contract.
• This decision was based on previous case law, such as Adams v Lindsell [1818] B & Ald 681 and Henthorn v Fraser [1892] 2 Ch 27, which established the 'postal rule' for determining where a contract is formed.
• The Court reasoned that as telex communications are instant, they should be treated differently from cases involving the postal system and adapted the rule accordingly.

Key passage(s)
• 'My conclusion is, that the rule about instantaneous communications between the parties is different from the rule about the post. The contract is only complete when the acceptance is received by the offeror: and the contract is made at the place where the acceptance is received.' (Lord Justice Denning)

cases.name: Household Fire and Carriage Accident Insurance Co Ltd v Grant [1879] 4 Ex D 216
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff (Household Fire and Carriage Accident Insurance Co Ltd) issued shares.
• The defendant (Grant) applied for shares, and the plaintiff accepted the application and sent an acceptance letter through the post.
• The letter was lost, and the defendant never received it.

Issues
• The issue was whether a contract was formed between the parties.
• The plaintiff argued that a contract was formed when they posted the acceptance letter.
• The defendant argued that there was no contract formed because he never received the acceptance letter.

Decision
• The court held that a contract was formed when the acceptance letter was posted.
• The posting rule, established in Adams v Lindsell (1818) 1 B & Ald 681, applied; acceptance is effective when it is posted, even if it is lost or delayed in transit.
• The defendant was therefore liable to pay for the shares.

Key passage(s)
• '… it seems to me … more consistent with the acts and declarations of the parties in this case to consider the contract complete and absolutely binding on the transmission of the notice of allotment through the post, as the medium of communication that the parties themselves contemplated, instead of postponing its completion until the notice had been received by the defendant.' (Thesiger LJ)

cases.name: Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd v Selfridge & Co Ltd [1915] AC 847
cases.summary:
Facts
• In a contract between Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd (Dunlop) and Dew & Co Ltd (Dew), Dunlop agreed to sell tyres to Dew subject to a resale price maintenance (RPM) agreement, which prevented Dew from selling the tyres below a certain price.
• Dew also agreed not to supply the tyres to any person it believed to be engaged in trading below the agreed price.
• Dew supplied tyres to Selfridge & Co Ltd (Selfridge) on condition that Selfridge maintained the agreed resale price.
• Selfridge sold the tyres at a lower price, and Dunlop sued Selfridge for breach of the RPM agreement.

Issues
• Dunlop argued that a collateral contract existed between them and Selfridge, which contained the RPM terms.
• Selfridge argued that there was no privity of contract (a direct contractual relationship) between them and Dunlop, as the only contract including the RPM terms was between Dunlop and Dew.
• The Court had to decide whether Dunlop could enforce the RPM agreement against Selfridge.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Dunlop could not enforce the RPM agreement against Selfridge, as there was no privity of contract between them.
• The Court confirmed the principle that only parties to a contract can sue/em/ on it or be sued under it.
• The decision established the 'doctrine of privity' as a fundamental principle of English contract law.

cases.name: Tweddle v Atkinson [1861] EWHC QB J57
cases.summary:
Facts
• Tweddle v Atkinson [1861] EWHC QB J57 is a foundational English contract law case that established the doctrine of privity of contract.
• The case involved an agreement made between the fathers of a couple who were to be married.
• The fathers promised each other that they would both make payment to the son-in-law, Tweddle, after the marriage.
• One of the fathers, Atkinson, failed to make the promised payment.
• The issue arose when Tweddle sued Atkinson for breach of contract after the death of both fathers.

Issues
• Tweddle argued that he was a party to the contract and was entitled to enforce the payment promise made by Atkinson.
• Atkinson argued that Tweddle was not a party to the contract between the fathers and therefore had no standing to sue for its enforcement.
• The case turned on whether Tweddle was entitled to enforce the promised payment as a third party to the contract.

Decision
• The English High Court held that Tweddle could not enforce the payment promise made by Atkinson.
• The court established the principle of privity of contract, which stipulates that only parties to a contract can enforce its terms or be subject to its liabilities.
• Tweddle, as a third party to the contract between the fathers, had no standing to sue for enforcement.

cases.name: Williams v Roffey Bros & Nicholls (Contractors) Ltd [1991] 1 QB 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Williams v Roffey Bros & Nicholls (Contractors) Ltd [1991] 1 QB 1, the defendants were building contractors.
• They subcontracted some carpentry work to the plaintiff, Mr. Williams, for a fixed price.
• The original contract was poorly estimated by Mr. Williams causing financial difficulties leading him to request an additional payment for each flat.
• Roffey Bros agreed to pay Williams the additional amount as they were keen to avoid the potentially costly delays of finding a new subcontractor.
• However, Roffey Bros did not pay the additional amount after Williams had completed several flats.
• Williams ceased work and claimed the additional payment.

Issues
• The main legal issue was whether the agreement to pay more constituted an enforceable contract given Williams' promise to complete work he was already contractually bound to complete.
• Roffey Bros argued that the promise of additional payment was not legally binding as the plaintiff provided no extra consideration for this promise and was merely performing an existing contractual duty.
• Williams contended that his performance of the existing duty constituted valid consideration for Roffey Bros' promise.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld Williams' claim and found the promise of additional payment to be enforceable.
• Their decision was based on the practical benefit doctrine, which was originated in the case of Stilk v Myrick (1809) 2 Camp 317, where a party could provide valid consideration by conferring some practical benefit upon the promisor.
• The court found that Roffey Bros had derived a practical benefit from the promise of additional payment, as it avoided the delays and likely termination of the original contract if Williams had not continued the work.

cases.name: Foakes v Beer [1884] UKHL 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Dr. Foakes owed Mrs. Beer a sum of money arising from a judgment debt and court costs.
• They reached an agreement in which Mrs. Beer accepted Dr. Foakes' undertaking to pay the debt by instalments.
• In return, Mrs. Beer agreed not to take any further action to enforce the debt and not to seek any interest on the debt.
• Upon Dr. Foakes paying the sum, Mrs. Beer claimed interest was still owed under the judgment and brought an action to recover it.

Issues
• Dr. Foakes argued that the earlier agreement constituted a binding contract, which barred Mrs. Beer from claiming interest.
• Mrs. Beer argued that the principle in Pinnel's Case (1602) applied, which states that part-payment of a debt does not discharge the whole debt unless there is some fresh consideration for the agreement.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the agreement was not binding as there was no consideration provided by Dr. Foakes.
• Since Dr. Foakes was only paying his existing legal obligation, the principle in Pinnel's Case applied, and Mrs. Beer was entitled to claim the unpaid interest.

Key passage(s)
• There must be ‘some independent benefit, actual of contingent, of a kind which might in law be a good and valuable consideration’. (Lord Selborne)

cases.name: Hadley & Anor v Baxendale & Ors [1854] EWHC J70
cases.summary:
Facts
• Hadley, the owner of a flour mill, had to shut down operations when the mill's crankshaft broke.
• He entered into a contract with Baxendale, a carrier, to transport the broken crankshaft to the manufacturer to create a replacement.
• Baxendale failed to deliver the crankshaft on the agreed date, causing Hadley to suffer additional financial losses due to the further delay in reopening the mill.
• Hadley sued Baxendale for these losses.

Issues
• Hadley argued that Baxendale was liable for all losses caused by the late delivery.
• Baxendale countered that he was not liable for losses he could not have reasonably foreseen at the time of entering the contract.

Decision
• The English court held that Baxendale was not liable for the losses suffered by Hadley because the damages were not within the 'reasonable contemplation' of the parties at the time the contract was made.
• The court established a rule for determining the extent of liability for breach of contract, known as the 'Hadley rule'.
• Under the Hadley rule, damages resulting from a breach of contract are only recoverable if they were reasonably foreseeable by both parties when entering into the contract, or if they arise naturally from the breach itself.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where two parties have made a contract which one of them has broken, the damages which the other party ought to receive in respect of such breach of contract should be such as may fairly and reasonably be considered either arising naturally, i.e., according to the usual course of things, from such breach of contract itself, or such as may reasonably be supposed to have been in the contemplation of both parties, at the time they made the contract, as the probable result of the breach of it.' (Alderson, B)

cases.name: Penn v Lord Baltimore (1750) 1 Ves Sen 444
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of Penn v Lord Baltimore (1750) involved a territorial dispute between the Penn family, proprietors of Pennsylvania, and Lord Baltimore of Maryland in Colonial America.
• In 1681, King Charles II granted a piece of land to the Penn family, later to become the Pennsylvania colony.
• In 1632, King Charles I granted land to Lord Baltimore, which became Maryland.
• The exact boundary between Pennsylvania and Maryland was not clearly defined, leading to territorial disputes between the Penn family and Lord Baltimore.
• In 1732, both parties entered into an agreement (the Articles of Agreement) setting the boundaries of their respective territories, but disputes continued.

Issues
• In 1750, the Penn family brought suit against Lord Baltimore in the English Court of Chancery, asking the court to enforce the 1732 agreement setting the boundaries, and to grant an injunction against Lord Baltimore.
• The Penn family argued that the Articles of Agreement were binding and should be enforced by the court, as they were the result of negotiations conducted by both parties.
• Lord Baltimore contended that the agreement was not binding because there was no enabling clause, no consideration, and that the agreement was not sufficiently specific.

Decision
• The Court of Chancery held that the 1732 agreement was binding and equitable, and should be enforced.
• The court granted an injunction against Lord Baltimore, preventing him from asserting any territorial claim beyond the agreed-upon boundary.
• The boundary line between the two colonies was ultimately determined by two surveyors, Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon, resulting in the Mason-Dixon Line.

Key passage(s)
• 'The conscience of the party was bound by this agreement and being within the jurisdiction of the court ... which acts in personam, the court may properly decree it ...' (Lord Hardwicke)

cases.name: Tulk v Moxhay [1848] EWHC Ch J34
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Tulk v Moxhay [1848] EWHC Ch J34, the claimant (Tulk) sold a piece of land to the defendant (Moxhay).
• The land included Leicester square gardens, which was subject to a covenant that restricted the use of the land to maintaining the gardens for the pleasure of the residents in the area (with no buildings or other use allowed).
• The covenant was included in the conveyance deed of the land.
• Some years later, Moxhay sold the land to another purchaser, wherein the covenant was not contained in the conveyance.
• This new purchaser then sold the land to another person (M to D), where the conveyance once again did not contain the covenant.
• Eventually, Moxhay sought to build on the land, which led Tulk to object and seek the enforcement of the covenant.

Issues
• The issue before the court was whether equity will enforce a restrictive covenant against a subsequent purchaser of the land who is on actual or constructive notice of the covenant, despite the covenant not being included in the conveyance.
• Tulk argued that the covenant should be enforceable against Moxhay because the court could infer that subsequent purchasers of the land would be bound by the covenant.
• Moxhay argued that the covenant should not be enforceable because restrictive covenants should not bind subsequent purchasers unless they had direct notice of the covenant, which Moxhay claimed he did not have.

Decision
• The court decided in favor of Tulk, holding that equity will enforce a restrictive covenant against subsequent purchasers of the land if they are on actual or constructive notice of the covenant, even if the covenant was not included in the conveyance of the land.
• The court reasoned that the covenant continued to run with the land, and was therefore enforceable against Moxhay, since he was on constructive notice of the covenant.
• The decision established the principle of notice, which asserts that subsequent purchasers of land are bound by any covenant on the land they are on notice of.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is said that, the covenant being one which does not run with the land, this court cannot enforce it, but the question is not whether the covenant runs with the land, but whether a party shall be permitted to use the land in a manner inconsistent with the contract entered into by his vendor, with notice of which he purchased. Of course, the price would be affected by the covenant, and nothing could be more inequitable than that the original purchaser should be able to sell the property the next day for a greater price, in consideration of the assignee being allowed to escape from the liability which he had himself undertaken …That the question does not depend on whether the covenant runs with the land is evident from this, that if there was a mere assignment and no covenant, this Court would enforce it against a party purchasing with notice of it; for if an equity is attached to the property by the owner, no one purchasing with notice of that equity can stand in a different situation from the party from whom he purchased.' (Lord Cottenham LC)

cases.name: Errington v Errington & Woods [1951] EWCA Civ 2, [1952] 1 KB 290
cases.summary:
Facts
• A father, the defendant, purchased a house for his daughter and son-in-law, who made mortgage repayments directly to the building society.
• The defendant orally promised to transfer the property to them once the mortgage had been paid.
• The marriage ended, and the son-in-law stopped making payments.
• The defendant took possession of the house and refused to transfer the property to his daughter or son-in-law.
• The daughter claimed she had a right to the beneficial ownership of the property.

Issues
• The claimant argued that there was an implied trust that benefits the daughter and son-in-law upon fulfillment of the oral condition.
• The defendant argued that the house was a gift to the couple (inter vivos), conditional upon payment of the mortgage.
• The defendant claimed the gift was incomplete since the condition had not been met, and thus the trust was invalid.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that an implied trust existed in favour of the daughter and son-in-law.
• The father could not revoke the trust once they had started to make the mortgage payments.
•The trust was not invalidated on the grounds of an unmet condition.

cases.name: Walsh v Lonsdale (1882) 21 Ch D 9
cases.summary:
Facts
• Walsh entered into an agreement to let a warehouse from Lonsdale.
• The agreement was made prior to the lease being executed in writing.
• Lonsdale sought to terminate the agreement on the grounds of non-payment of rent and arrears.
• Walsh claimed he was entitled to continue the occupation of the warehouse due to the agreement.

Issues
• Whether the prior agreement to let the warehouse was sufficient to create a legal right for Walsh to continue to occupy the property.
• Whether Lonsdale had the right to terminate the agreement on the grounds of non-payment of rent and arrears.
• Walsh argued that the rights and obligations in an equitable lease should be specifically enforced and the occupant should enjoy full ownership.
• Lonsdale contended that Walsh's rights were insufficient to prevent the termination of the agreement as there was no legal lease.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that Walsh's equitable lease was effectively the same as a legal lease due to the Maxims of Equity that dictated equity follows the law.
• Hence, Lonsdale was not permitted to terminate the agreement on the grounds of non-payment.
• The decision in this case established the principle that equity will enforce legal obligations (specific performance) even though they have yet to be formalised in writing.

Key passage(s)
• 'The tenant holds under an agreement for a lease. He holds, therefore, under the same terms in equity as if a lease had been granted, it being a case in which both parties admit that relief is capable of being given by specific performance. That being so, he cannot complain of the exercise by the landlord of the same rights as the landlord would have had if a lease had been granted. On the other hand, he is protected in the same way as if a lease had been granted; he cannot be turned out by six months’ notice as a tenant from year to year.' (Lord Jessel MR)

cases.name: Re Rose [1952] EWCA Civ 4
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Re Rose [1952] EWCA Civ 4, Mr. Rose transferred shares he owned in a family company to three trustees for the benefit of his wife and daughter.
• The transfer was not immediate and was only completed several months later when the share certificates and transfer forms were handed over to the trustees.
• Mr. Rose died in the meantime, and his executors argued that the gift was incomplete and therefore the shares formed part of his estate for tax purposes (Estate Duty).

Issues
• The main issue debated was whether Mr. Rose had done everything in his power to transfer the shares, thus constituting a complete gift in terms of equity.
• The executors argued that Mr. Rose's actions were not enough to complete the gift, while the trustees maintained that the gift was complete as Mr. Rose had done everything he could to effect the transfer of the shares.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the gift was complete, as Mr. Rose had done everything in his power to make the transfer.
• The court relied on the principles established in Milroy v Lord (1862) as well as Mascall v Mascall (1886) in reaching its decision. These cases emphasized that in order for an equity to recognize a completed gift, the donor must have done all in his power to transfer the property.
• The court further held that Mr. Rose's actions to transfer the shares had removed them from his estate, therefore reducing the Estate Duty payable.

cases.name: Lloyds Bank v Rosset [1990] UKHL 14, [1991] 1 AC 107
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Mr. Rosset, purchased a house in joint names with his wife using funds borrowed from the respondent, Lloyds Bank.
• Mrs. Rosset spent considerable time and money renovating the property, believing that this would give her a beneficial interest in the property.
• When Mr. Rosset defaulted on the loan, Lloyds Bank sought to repossess the property, claiming that Mrs. Rosset had no beneficial interest in it.

Issues
• Lloyds Bank argued that Mrs. Rosset did not have a beneficial interest in the property because there was no express agreement between the parties, and her contributions did not amount to a constructive trust.
• Mrs. Rosset contended that she had a beneficial interest in the property under a constructive trust due to her direct financial and labor contributions.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Mrs. Rosset did not have a beneficial interest in the property.
• There was no evidence of an express agreement between the parties, and her contributions did not amount to a constructive trust as they were not directly related to the initial acquisition of the property.
• Consequently, Lloyds Bank was entitled to repossess the property.

Key passage(s)
• 'The first and fundamental question which must always be resolved is whether, independently of any inference to be drawn from the conduct of the parties in the course of sharing the house as their home and managing their joint affairs, there has at any time prior to acquisition, or exceptionally at some later date, been any agreement, arrangement or understanding reached between them that the property is to be shared beneficially. The finding of an agreement or arrangement to share in this sense can only, I think, be based on evidence of express discussions between the partners, however imperfectly remembered and however imprecise their terms may have been. Once a finding to this effect is made it will only be necessary for the partner asserting a claim to a beneficial interest against the partner entitled to the legal estate to show that he or she has acted to his or her detriment or significantly altered his or her position in reliance on the agreement in order to give rise to a constructive trust or a proprietary estoppel.': Lord Bridge
• 'It was common ground that Mrs. Rosset was extremely anxious that the new matrimonial home should be ready for occupation before Christmas if possible. In these circumstances it would seem the most natural thing in the world for any wife, in the absence of her husband abroad, to spend all the time she could spare and to employ any skills she might have, such as the ability to decorate a room, in doing all she could to accelerate progress of the work quite irrespective of any expectation she might have of enjoying a beneficial interest in the property.': Lord Bridge

cases.name: Factortame Ltd v Secretary of State for Transport (No 2) [1991] 1 AC 603
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the 1980s, a number of Spanish fishing companies, including Factortame Ltd, registered their vessels in the UK to take advantage of the British fishing quotas.
• In response, the UK government enacted the Merchant Shipping Act 1988 and created the Merchant Shipping (Registration of Fishing Vessels) Regulations 1988.
• The Act required companies owning fishing vessels to be 75% British-owned, effectively excluding Factortame Ltd and other Spanish companies.
• Factortame Ltd sought judicial review, claiming the Act breached their rights under European Community (EC) law, specifically under the Treaty of the European Economic Community (EEC).

Issues
• Factortame Ltd argued that the UK's Merchant Shipping Act and the Regulations were inconsistent with their rights of freedom of establishment and non-discrimination provided under Articles 52 and 221 of the Treaty of the EEC.
• The Secretary of State for Transport argued that the Act and the Regulations were valid and necessary to preserve the UK's fishing industry and protect resources.
• A key issue was whether UK courts had the power to disapply UK legislation that conflicted with EC law.

Decision
• The House of Lords held in favour of Factortame Ltd, ruling that UK courts have the power to disapply UK legislation that conflicts with EC law.
• This case reaffirmed the decision in R v Secretary of State for Employment, ex parte Equal Opportunities Commission [1994] 1 AC 1, which established that EC law has direct effect and supremacy over domestic laws.

cases.name: Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen [1963] ECR 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Van Gend en Loos (VGL), a Dutch transport company, imported chemicals from Germany into the Netherlands.
• The Dutch government increased its customs duties on the imported chemicals, which VGL challenged as violating the European Economic Community (EEC) Treaty.
• VGL argued that the increase was unlawful under Article 12 of the Treaty.
• The legal dispute was referred to the European Court of Justice (ECJ) for a preliminary ruling.

Issues
• The key question was whether VGL could rely on Article 12 and claim damages from the Dutch government for unlawfully increased duties.
• VGL argued that the Treaty had created fundamental rights, which could be relied upon by individuals.
• The Dutch government argued that the Treaty provisions could only impose obligations on Member States and not give rights to individuals.

Decision
• The ECJ held that certain provisions of the Treaty could create rights for individuals, which national courts must protect.
• The ECJ introduced the concept of 'direct effect,' meaning that individuals could rely on Treaty provisions in national courts if the provisions met certain conditions.
