• Upon realizing the mistake, the defendant refused to pay for the tow lot, and the plaintiff sued for the price.

Issues
• The issue was whether there was a valid contract between the parties or whether it was void for mutual mistake as to the subject matter of the contract.
• The plaintiff argued that there was a contract and the defendant was obligated to pay for the tow.
• The defendant argued that there was no contract due to mutual mistake, as there was no consensus ad idem (meeting of the minds).

Decision
• The court held that there was no contract between the parties due to mutual mistake, resulting in a lack of consensus ad idem.
• The plaintiff had not made the hemp and tow samples sufficiently clear, whilst the defendant had not brought a catalogue to the auction or inspected the samples carefully before bidding.

Key passage(s)
• 'Such a contract cannot arise when the person seeking to enforce it has by his own negligence or by that of those for whom he is responsible caused, or contributed to cause, the mistake.' (A.T. Lawrence J)

cases.name: Gray v Thames Trains Ltd [2009] 1 AC 1339
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Gray, was involved in a train crash caused by Thames Trains Ltd's negligence where he suffered from severe post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
• Due to his PTSD, Gray killed a pedestrian in a separate incident and was incarcerated.
• Gray sued Thames Trains Ltd for the loss of earnings resulting from his imprisonment and the criminal act he committed under the influence of PTSD.

Issues
• The Court had to decide if Gray’s claim for loss of earnings due to imprisonment was recoverable in tort for Thames Trains Ltd’s negligence causing the PTSD.
• Gray argued that the 'narrow rule' in Clunis v Camden and Islington Health Authority [1998] QB 978 should apply, only barring recovery for direct consequences of the criminal conduct.
• Thames Trains Ltd argued for the application of the 'wide rule', barring recovery for loss of earnings resulting from imprisonment entirely due to public policy considerations and the illegality principle.

Decision
• The House of Lords rejected Gray's claim for lost earnings.
• The Court applied the 'wide rule' on the grounds of illegality and public policy, disallowing Gray’s claim for his loss of earnings during imprisonment.
• This was because he shouldn't be able to recover damages due to a criminal sanction caused by his own criminal act.

Key passage(s)
• 'The law cannot at one and the same time incarcerate someone for his criminality and compensate him civilly for the financial consequences.' (Lord Brown)

cases.name: Clunis v Camden HA [1998] QB 978
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Claimant, who had a mental disorder, was detained in a hospital and then discharged.
• Who months later, the Claimant stabbed a stranger to death in an unprovoked attack and thereafter, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.
• He was sentenced to be detained in a hospital pursuant to section 37 of the Mental Health Act 1983 with an indefinite restriction order under section 41.
• The Claimant sued the Health Authority, alleging negligence in discharging him and not providing adequate aftercare and claimed damages for his loss of liberty.

Issues
• The Health Authority sought to strike out the action, arguing that even if it was negligent and had they not discharged the Claimant, he would not have committed manslaughter. Moreover, damages could not be recovered for the consequences of the Claimant's own unlawful act.
• The Claimant argued that the Health Authority's negligence led to his actions and subsequent loss of liberty.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal allowed the Defendant's appeal, striking out the Claimant's action.
• The Court held that public policy precluded the court from entertaining the Claimant's claim, as he had been convicted of a serious criminal offence and knew his actions were wrong.
• Although the Claimant's responsibility for the killing was diminished, his mental state did not justify a verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity.

Key passage(s)
• Beldam LJ: 'In the present case the plaintiff has been convicted of a serious criminal offence. In such a case public policy would in our judgment preclude the court from entertaining the plaintiff's claim unless it could be said that he did not know the nature and quality of his act or that what he was doing was wrong...The court ought not to allow itself to be made an instrument to enforce obligations alleged to arise out of the plaintiff's own criminal act and we would therefore allow the appeal on this ground.'

cases.name: Lister v Hesley Hall Ltd [2001] UKHL 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Lister v Hesley Hall Ltd [2001] A.C. 215 involved tort claims of sexual abuse by an employee (the Warden, the Listers) against children residing in a boarding house operated by the Hesley Hall Ltd.
• The abuse occurred while the Warden was performing his duties, which required him to reside with and care for the children in the boarding house.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether Hesley Hall Ltd, as the employer, could be held vicariously liable for the wrongful acts of the Warden.
• The claimants argued that the employer should be held vicariously liable since the abuse occurred during the Warden's employment while performing his duties.
• On the other hand, the employer argued that it should not be held liable as the wrongful acts were not committed within the scope of the Warden's employment.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Hesley Hall Ltd was indeed vicariously liable for the Warden's wrongful acts.
• Their decision was based on the 'close connection' test, which states that if the wrongful acts are so closely connected to the employment that it would be fair and just to hold the employer liable, then vicarious liability can be imposed.
• In this case, they found that the Warden abused his position and authority as an employee of the boarding house, and this was sufficiently closely connected to his employment for the employer to be held liable.

Key passage(s)
• ' The question is whether the warden's torts were so closely connected with his employment that it would be fair and just to hold the employers vicariously liable. On the facts of the case the answer is yes. After all, the sexual abuse was inextricably interwoven with the carrying out by the warden of his duties in Axeholme House. Matters of degree arise. But the present cases clearly fall on the side of vicarious liability.' (Lord Steyn)

cases.name: Michael v Chief Constable of South Wales Police [2015] UKSC 2
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Michael v Chief Constable of South Wales Police [2015] UKSC 2, the claimant called the police after receiving a threat from her ex-partner.
• The police misclassified her call, resulting in a delayed response and her eventual death at the hands of her ex-partner.
• The claimant's estate brought a claim against the police alleging that their negligence caused her death.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the police owed a duty of care to individuals in the claimant's position.
• The claimant's estate argued that a duty of care arose because the police's negligence created a foreseeable risk of harm, and there was a sufficiently proximate relationship between the parties.
• The police argued that they did not owe a duty of care, as they are generally not liable for omissions in providing assistance, citing cases such as Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire [1989] AC 53.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the police were not liable.
• It reasoned that the police do not owe a duty of care for their acts or omissions in the course of investigating or preventing crime save for certain exceptions, such as where they create a danger or assume responsibility for someone's safety.
• The court found no exceptional circumstances here that would give rise to a duty of care. Importantly, the court held that public authorities should be subject to the ordinary principles of negligence.

cases.name: James-Bowen v Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis [2018] UKSC 40
cases.summary:
Facts
• In James-Bowen v Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis, four Metropolitan Police officers were involved in an arrest and alleged assault of a terrorist suspect back in 2003. After the incident, the suspect sued the force, claiming damages for assault and negligence.
• The Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis settled the claim, paying out damages without any admission of liability. However, the four police officers brought a claim in tort against the Commissioner, arguing that he did not defend their innocence and seeking indemnification

Issues
• The question before the UK Supreme Court was whether the Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis owed a duty of care to its police officers in a potentially tortious act and whether he was obliged to indemnify them.
• The police officers argued that the Commissioner owed them a duty of care and should protect them from having to meet a third-party claim.
• On the other hand, the Commissioner contended that he did not and that such an obligation fell outside of the scope of an employer-employee relationship

Decision
• The Court held unanimously that the Commissioner did not owe a duty of care or indemnification to the four police officers against potential third-party claims.
• The Court noted that 'such a duty had not previously been identified and acknowledging it would raise significant public policy challenges.'
• The Court also cited the previous case of Friar v Newham London Borough Council [2011] EWCA Civ 281, where a duty of care to protect from pure economic loss was also rejected

Key passage(s)
• 'As Lord Reed explained in Robinson, in determining whether such a duty should be recognised the law will proceed incrementally and by analogy with previous decisions.' (Lord Lloyd-Jones)
• 'If a Chief Constable does not, in principle, owe a duty of care to protect the economic and reputational interests of his officers in respect of the prosecution of an investigation or disciplinary proceedings, it is difficult to see why he should owe a duty to his officers as to the manner in which he defends a claim brought against him by a third party.' (Lord Lloyd-Jones)

cases.name: GN v Poole Borough Council [2019] UKSC 25
cases.summary:
Facts
• In GN v Poole Borough Council [2019] UKSC 25, the claimants (GN and CN) alleged that the defendant local authority (Poole Borough Council) failed in its duty to protect them from harassment and abuse by a neighboring family, resulting in physical harm and psychological trauma.
• GN and CN were young children and their family were receiving social services assistance from the local authority at the time. The claimants' family requested a transfer to a different housing location but were denied.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the local authority owed a duty of care to the claimants under the principles of tort and negligence.
• The claimants argued that the local authority's failure to protect them or relocate their family demonstrated negligence in their duty of care.
• The local authority argued that, as a public body exercising statutory discretion, it did not owe the claimants a duty of care.

Decision
• The Supreme Court dismissed the claimants' appeal, agreeing with the local authority that it did not owe the claimants a duty of care.
• The Court reasoned that imposing a duty of care on local authorities in such cases would lead to a risk of defensive practices and diversion of resources from their statutory functions.
• The Court relied on previous cases such as Mitchell v Glasgow City Council [2009] UKHL 11 and Michael v Chief Constable of South Wales [2015] UKSC 2 to reinforce that public authorities do not owe a general duty of care to protect individuals from harm caused by third parties.

cases.name: Smith v Eric S. Bush [1990] UKHL 1, [1989] 2 WLR 790
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Smith v Eric S. Bush [1989] 3 WLR 790, the defendants were surveyors instructed by the plaintiffs' mortgage lender to value the plaintiffs' house.
• The plaintiffs purchased the house for £35,000 based on the defendants' valuation.
• It was later discovered that the house suffered from structural defects requiring extensive repair work, causing the property value to be worth much less.
• The plaintiffs sued the defendants for negligent misstatement, claiming that they breached their duty of care by providing a valuation that significantly overestimated the house's actual worth.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether the defendants owed a duty of care to the plaintiffs, resulting in liability for negligent misstatement.
• The defendants argued that no duty of care was owed because they were chosen by and acted solely for the mortgage lender, with no direct relationship with the plaintiffs.
• The plaintiffs argued that such a duty existed, as they relied on the valuation provided by the defendants when deciding to purchase the house.

Decision
• The court held in favour of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendants owed a duty of care to the plaintiffs.
• The court noted that surveyors providing valuations owe a duty of care to house buyers who reasonably rely on their advice. This was based on the test established in Hedley Byrne v Heller & Partners Ltd [1964] AC 465, that a duty of care arises when there is reliance on advice given in a situation where the adviser knows, or ought reasonably to know, that the recipient relies and intends to act on that advice.
• In this case, the defendants knew or ought to have known that their valuation would be relied upon by the plaintiffs in deciding whether to purchase.

cases.name: Banca Nazionale del Lavoro SPA v Playboy Club London Ltd [2018] UKSC 43
cases.summary:
Facts
• Banca Nazionale del Lavoro (BNL) provided a reference to London Clubs Management Ltd, a subsidiary of Playboy Club London Ltd (Playboy).
• In reliance on this reference, Playboy allowed Hassan Bakarat to gamble on its premises and suffer losses.
• Later, it emerged that BNL had neither made proper inquiries about Bakarat's financial position nor confirmed his creditworthiness.
• Playboy sued BNL for negligence and claimed that the bank should be held accountable for its losses.

Issues
• Whether a tort of negligent misstatement could be established given that there was no direct relationship between BNL and Playboy.
• Playboy's argument: BNL breached a duty of care owed to it by providing a negligently-prepared letter of credit in favor of Bakarat.
• BNL's argument: BNL did not owe a duty of care to Playboy.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court dismissed Playboy's appeal.
• The Court confirmed that there must be 'reasonable foreseeability of harm' and a 'sufficient relationship of proximity' between the parties for a tort of negligent misstatement to be established.
• The Court held that BNL owed no duty of care to Playboy as the relationship between the two parties was not 'proximate' enough.

cases.name: Fearn v Tate Gallery Board of Trustees [2020] EWCA Civ 104
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimants, owners of flats in a building overlooking Tate Modern's public terrace, sued the Tate Gallery Board of Trustees alleging a breach of privacy due to the museum's viewing platform.
• They claimed that the platform constituted an actionable nuisance and sought an injunction to restrict access to the platform.
• Their claim was dismissed in the High Court, and they appealed to the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• The claimants contended that the Tate's platform invasion of their privacy amounted to an actionable nuisance.
• The defendants, however, argued that the claimants had no reasonable expectation of privacy as the flats had floor-to-ceiling windows and were in close proximity to public spaces, nor does the tort of nuisance cover interference with one's privacy.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's decision.
• Lawton LJ opined that the tort of nuisance should not be extended to encompass an invasion of privacy, as it generally deals with land-related disputes.
• The court emphasized that a claim for privacy infringement should be based on Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and not the tort of nuisance.
• The court also noted that to hold otherwise would create a new and independent tort of 'overlooking', and this was a matter for Parliament to decide.
• Accordingly, the claimants' appeal was dismissed.

cases.name: Cox v Ministry of Justice [2016] UKSC 10
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Cox v Ministry of Justice [2016] UKSC 10, the claimant, Mrs. Cox, was a catering manager at a prison, working under the Ministry of Justice.
• During the course of her work, she sustained an injury when a sack of rice fell onto her, leading to her suffering a back injury.
• The sack was being carried by a prisoner who was working in the kitchen as part of a prison work program.

Issues
• The key legal issue in this case was whether the Ministry of Justice could be held vicariously liable for the tortious acts of the prisoner (negligence).
• The Ministry of Justice argued that there was no vicarious liability, as there was no employment relationship between them and the prisoner.
• On the other hand, Mrs. Cox argued that the prison context and relationship was sufficient to establish vicarious liability.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the Ministry of Justice was vicariously liable for the prisoner's negligence.
• In reaching this decision, the court applied the two-stage test for vicarious liability established in Catholic Child Welfare Society v Various Claimants [2012] UKSC 56 (CCWS):
1. Is there a relationship between the defendant (Ministry of Justice) and the tortfeasor (prisoner) that is capable of giving rise to vicarious liability?
2. Is there a sufficiently 'close connection' between the relationship and the tortious act?
• The court concluded that both elements were satisfied and therefore, the Ministry of Justice was vicariously liable.

Key passage
• 'In the present case, the requirements laid down in the Christian Brothers case are met. The prison service carries on activities in furtherance of its aims. … Prisoners working in the prison kitchens, such as Mr Inder, are integrated into the operation of the prison, so that the activities assigned to them by the prison service form an integral part of the activities which it carries on in the furtherance of its aims: in particular, the activity of providing meals for prisoners. They are placed by the prison service in a position where there is a risk that they may commit a variety of negligent acts within the field of activities assigned to them. That is recognised by the health and safety training which they receive. Furthermore, they work under the direction of prison staff. Mrs Cox was injured as a result of negligence by Mr Inder in carrying on the activities assigned to him. The prison service is therefore vicariously liable to her.' (Lord Reed at para. 32)

cases.name: Wilkes v DePuy International Ltd [2016] EWHC 3096 (QB)
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Wilkes v DePuy International Ltd, the claimant, Keith Wilkes, sued DePuy International Ltd (DIL) for damages based on product liability and negligence in relation to a failed hip replacement.
• In 2007, Wilkes underwent a total hip replacement surgery during which he was fitted with the Pinnacle Ultamet Metal-on-Metal Acetabular Cup System (Ultamet) manufactured by DIL.
• In 2010, Wilkes experienced pain and other symptoms due to the presence of metal particles in his body, leading to the revision of his hip replacement in 2011.

Issues
• Whether DIL was in breach of the Consumer Protection Act 1987 (CPA) for supplying a defective Ultamet hip replacement system.
• Whether DIL was negligent in designing, manufacturing, and providing instructions and warnings in relation to the Ultamet system.
• DIL argued that the Ultamet system met the legal requirements and was not defective under the CPA, and that it was not negligent in its design, manufacturing, and provision of instructions and warnings.

Decision
• The court held that DIL was not in breach of the CPA because the Ultamet system was not considered a defective product.
• The court held that DIL was not negligent in designing, manufacturing, and providing instructions and warnings in relation to the Ultamet system.
• Therefore, Wilkes's claim was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• '...the fact that a safer design can be envisaged does not mean that a current product is defective' - (Hickinbottom J)

cases.name: X and others (minors) v Bedfordshire County Council [1995] 3 All ER 353
cases.summary:
Facts
• In X v Bedfordshire CC, several individuals who had been subject to child abuse sued their respective local authorities for negligence.
• The claimants alleged that the local authorities failed to take appropriate steps to protect them from harm while under the authorities' care, and the claimants had sustained harm as a result.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether the local authorities owed a duty of care in negligence.
• The claimants argued that they were owed a duty of care by the local authorities to prevent harm as they were under the authorities' care.
• The local authorities, on the other hand, argued that they did not owe a duty of care as they were acting as statutory bodies in performing their safeguarding functions.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the local authorities did not owe a duty of care to the claimants.
• The court reasoned that the imposition of a duty of care on local authorities in these circumstances would interfere with their statutory discretion in child protection matters.
• The court also took into consideration the potential for diversion of resources away from the provision of services if local authorities could be sued for negligence.

cases.name: Owens v Brimmell [1977] QB 859
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Owens v Brimmell [1977] QB 859, the claimant, Owens, and defendant, Brimmell, went to several public houses together in which both consumed alcohol.
• Owens agreed to drive Brimmell to his home.
• While driving, Owens lost control of his car and collided with another vehicle, causing injuries to both parties.
• Both Owens and Brimmell were found to be intoxicated with amounts of alcohol in their blood above the legal limit.

Issues
• Owens brought a claim against Brimmell for damages in the tort of negligence.
• Brimmell argued that Owens was contributorily negligent and therefore should bear some responsibility for his own injuries.
• Owens rejected this argument and insisted that Brimmell's negligence was the sole cause of the accident and resulting injuries.

Decision
• The court held that both Owens and Brimmell were negligent.
• As a result, the damages awarded to Owens were reduced by 20% to reflect his contributory negligence.

Key passage(s)
• '...a passenger [may] be guilty of contributory negligence if he, knowing that he is going to be driven in a car by his companion later, accompanies him upon a bout of drinking which has the effect, eventually, of robbing the passenger of clear thought and perception and diminishes the driver’s capacity to drive properly and carefully.' (Watkins J)

cases.name: Smith v Finch [2009] EWHC 53
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the case of Smith v Finch [2009] EWHC 53, the claimant, Mr. Smith, was involved in a motorcycle accident with the defendant, Mr. Finch.
• Mr. Smith was riding a motorcycle without wearing a helmet at the time of the accident, which occurred when the defendant pulled out of a side road and collided with the claimant's motorcycle.
• Mr. Smith suffered a head injury as a result of the accident and sought damages from the defendant.

Issues
• The main issues in the case were whether Mr. Finch was liable for the accident and whether Mr. Smith's failure to wear a helmet amounted to contributory negligence.
• The defendant argued that the claimant's failure to wear a helmet contributed to his injuries and therefore, reduced his entitlement to damages.
• The claimant, on the other hand, argued that his head injury would have occurred even if he had been wearing a helmet.

Decision
• The court held that the defendant was liable for the accident, as he had pulled out of a side road without ensuring it was safe to do so.
• However, the court also found that failure to wear a helmet amounted to contributory negligence when, on the facts of the case, the injuries would have been reduced by wearing a helmet.
• On the facts of this case, this could not be proven and thus there was no contributory negligence.

cases.name: Jones v Livox Quarries [1952] 2 QB 608
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant (C) worked in the defendant's (D) quarry.
• C breached company rules by hitching a ride on the tow bar of a traxcavator. The traxcavator driver was unaware of C's actions.
• A dumper truck, driven recklessly by another employee, collided with the traxcavator, causing severe injuries to C's legs which were later amputated.
• C sued D for negligence.

Issues
• C argued that D was liable for the injuries due to the reckless action of the dumper truck driver.
• D argued that C's contributory negligence, by breaching the company rules and exposing himself to danger, should reduce or eliminate their liability.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that D was liable, but C was 20% to blame under the Law Reform (Contributory Negligence) Act 1945.
• The court found that C acted against orders and exposed himself to danger, which contributed to his injuries.

Key passage(s)
• 'A person is guilty of contributory negligence if he ought reasonably to have foreseen that, if he did not act as a reasonable, prudent man, he might be hurt himself: and in his reckonings he must take into account the possibility of others being careless.' (Denning LJ)

cases.name: Jackson v Murray [2015] UKSC 5
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Jackson v Murray [2015] UKSC 5, the claimant, a 13-year-old child, was seriously injured in a road accident.
• The claimant had alighted from a bus and was crossing the road in front of the bus, and was hit by a car driven by the defendant.
• At the trial, it was accepted that the child's own negligence contributed to the accident - the child was racing with another child across the road without checking if it was safe.
• The trial judge assessed the damages at 90%. On appeal, this was reduced to 70%.

Issues
• The main issue was the apportionment of liability between the claimant and the defendant. The defendant argued that the trial judge had not applied the correct approach to apportionment because the claimant's greater contributory negligence should have resulted in a higher percentage of liability.
• The claimant argued that the trial judge correctly balanced the respective blameworthiness of both parties and the causative potency of their conduct.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the trial judge had applied the correct approach to apportionment but had nevertheless assessed the claimant's share of responsibility too high.
• The Court applied the test in Stapley v Gypsum Mines Ltd [1953] AC 663: the factors relevant to apportionment were those those affecting the parties' responsibility for the damage, i.e. their blameworthiness and the causative potency of their conduct.
• The Court reduced the damages to 50%.

Key passage(s)
• '...it is only a difference of view as to the apportionment of responsibility which exceeds the ambit of reasonable disagreement that warrants the conclusion that the court below has gone wrong.' (Lord Reed).

cases.name: R (on the application of Bancoult No 3) v Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs [2018] UKSC 3
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Chagos Refugees Group challenged the Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs' decision to establish a marine protected area (MPA) surrounding the Chagos Archipelago in the British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT).
• Chagossians were resettled elsewhere by the British Government between 1971 and 1973, and it remained prohibited under the BIOT Constitution and Immigration Orders 2004 for Chagossians to return.
• The cable in question, purportedly from the US Embassy, appeared to show that the MPA was created to make future resettlement by Chagossians impracticable.

Issues
• The creation of the MPA allegedly amounted to an improper ulterior motive.
• The consultation process preceding the decision was flawed by failing to disclose potential fishing rights held by Mauritius.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously held that the cable should have been admitted as evidence before the Administrative Court.
• A majority dismissed the appeal on the improper ulterior motive ground, holding that even if the cable was genuine, it could not materially change the outcome of the case.
• The appeal was also unanimously dismissed regarding the issue of consultation and fishing rights, as Mauritius had the opportunity to assert such rights during the consultation.

cases.name: R (on the application of Bancoult (No 2)) v Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs [2016] UKSC 35
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Chagos Islands, or British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT), had a settled population of 1,000 in 1962.
• In 1966, the UK agreed to let the USA use Diego Garcia, the largest island, as a military base.
• The BIOT Commissioner made an Immigration Ordinance in 1971 that effectively barred the indigenous Chagossians from the islands.
• The appellant, Mr. Bancoult, obtained a High Court order quashing the Ordinance in 2000, leading to the Government ordering a feasibility study into resettlement.
• In 2004, the BIOT Constitution Order introduced a new prohibition on residence in BIOT.
• The appellant's challenge to the 2004 Order was dismissed by a majority in the House of Lords in 2008 (R (Bancoult) (No 2)).
• The appellant sought to set aside the 2008 Decision based on the non-disclosure of certain documents and the emergence of new evidence.

Issues
• The appellant argued that the undisclosed documents cast doubt on the 2008 Decision and that the fresh evidence justified setting it aside.
• The respondent argued that the appellant failed to meet the threshold for non-disclosure and that the fresh evidence was insufficient to set aside the 2008 Decision.

Decision
• The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by a majority of 3 to 2, upholding the 2008 Decision.
• The Court held that there was no probability that the fresh evidence would have led to a different outcome in the initial 2008 judgment, nor any basis for setting it aside.
• Additionally, the Court noted that circumstances have since changed, and it is now open to Chagossians to mount a fresh challenge to the 2004 Order based on the findings of the 2014-15 study.

cases.name: R (on the application of Moseley (in substitution of Stirling Deceased)) v London Borough of Haringey [2014] UKSC 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Local Government Finance Act 1992 required local authorities to consult with interested persons on their Council Tax Reduction Scheme (CTRS) draft form.
• The London Borough of Haringey conducted a consultation on its draft CTRS, focusing on a reduction in council tax relief for claimants.
• The Appellant argued that the consultation process was unfair and unlawful.

Issues
• The Appellant claimed that the consultation was unfair and unlawful because other options for addressing the council tax shortfall were not mentioned in the document.
• The Respondent contended that the consultation met the statutory requirements under the Local Government Finance Act 1992.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously held that the consultation was unfair and unlawful, applying the requirements of procedural fairness as outlined in R v Brent London Borough Council, ex p Gunning.
• The Court held that the Respondent should have included reference to alternative methods of addressing the shortfall in the consultation document to allow for meaningful public participation.
• However, the Court declined to order a fresh consultation exercise, as it would be disproportionate in the circumstances.

cases.name: R (on the application of Chester) (Appellant) v Secretary of State for Justice (Respondent) [2013] UKSC 63
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellants, both serving life sentences for murder, claim that their rights have been and are being infringed because they are not entitled to vote.
• UK law contains a general prohibition on prisoner voting, which the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) has found incompatible with Article 3 of Protocol No 1 (A3P1) of the European Convention on Human Rights (the Convention).
• Chester relies on A3P1, as incorporated into domestic law by the Human Rights Act, and also on European Union (EU) law. McGeoch relies solely on EU law.
• Both claims were dismissed by the courts below.

Issues
• The Supreme Court must address: (a) whether it should apply principles from Hirst (No 2); (b) whether the current ban on voting is incompatible with Chester's rights under A3P1 and the Supreme Court should make a further declaration of incompatibility under the Human Rights Act; (c) whether EU law recognizes an individual right to vote, which the appellants can rely upon; and (d) what consequences and relief would be available to Chester and McGeoch if EU law were to recognize an individual right to vote.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed both appeals, applying Hirst (No 2) and Scoppola principles but declining to make any further declaration of incompatibility in respect of Chester.
• It was found that EU law does not provide an individual right to vote paralleling that recognized by ECtHR in its case law.
• The resolution of both appeals did not require a reference to the Court of Justice of the European Union.

cases.name: Kennedy (Appellant) v The Charity Commission (Respondent) [2014] UKSC 20
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr. Kennedy, a journalist, requested information from the Charity Commission under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) regarding inquiries into the 'Mariam Appeal'
• The Charity Commission refused the request, citing the absolute exemption contained in section 32(2) of the FOIA

Issues
• The issues before the Supreme Court were whether the exemption applied and if it conflicted with Mr. Kennedy's rights under article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights
• If there was a conflict, the court would need to examine if section 32 could be read down to maintain compatibility or if a declaration of incompatibility would need to be made

Decision
• The majority of the court agreed with Lord Mance and Lord Toulson's judgments, finding that section 32(2) imposes an absolute exemption and that Mr. Kennedy is not assisted by relying on the Convention
• The Charities Act 1993 and common law put Mr. Kennedy in no less favorable position for obtaining information
• The court would have concluded that Article 10 did not contain a freestanding right to receive information from public authorities had it been necessary

cases.name: Steel and another v NRAM Limited [2018] UKSC 13
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 2007, the First Appellant, a solicitor, represented a company that sought to discharge security over one unit of a property while maintaining the security over other units.
• The Appellant emailed NRAM (the Respondent), inaccurately stating that the whole loan was being paid off, and obtained executed deeds that mistakenly discharged the security over all the remaining units.
• The security discharge went unnoticed until 2010 when the company went into liquidation, causing NRAM to claim damages against the Appellant alleging negligence and breach of duty of care.

Issues
• The issue was whether the Appellant owed a duty of care to NRAM and should be held liable for negligent misrepresentation.
• The Appellant argued that they did not assume responsibility for the representations, and that NRAM’s reliance on the email was not reasonable or foreseeable.
• NRAM contended that the Appellant had assumed responsibility, citing factors such as the solicitor's expertise and NRAM not having instructed its own solicitors.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and restored the interlocutor of the Lord Ordinary.
• The Court held that assumption of responsibility remains the foundation of liability for negligent misrepresentation, emphasizing the need for reasonable and foreseeable reliance by the representee, as well as reasonable foreseeability by the representor.
• In this case, the Court found it was not reasonable for NRAM to have relied on the email without verifying its accuracy, and held that the Appellant did not assume responsibility towards NRAM.

cases.name: Coventry and others v Lawrence and another [2015] UKSC 50
cases.summary:
Facts
• This case stems from a claim in nuisance by owners of a bungalow against nearby stadium operators.
• The owners claimed on a 'no win, no fee' basis, incurring a success fee and insurance premium payable by the stadium operators upon the owners' success at trial.
• The stadium operators challenged the recovery of the success fee and insurance premium, suggesting that it violated their rights to a fair trial and right to peaceful enjoyment of possessions.
Issues
• The main issue is whether the Access to Justice Act 1999's system for costs recovery is compatible with the European Convention on Human Rights.
• The Appellants argued it was a proportionate way of achieving the legitimate aim of giving the public access to civil litigation funded by the private sector.
• The Respondents claimed there were flaws within the system, notably unfocused regulation, lack of control on legal costs, and uneven treatment of defendants, rendering it disproportionate.
Decision
• By a majority of 5-2, the UK Supreme Court held that the Access to Justice Act 1999 regime is compatible with the European Convention on Human Rights.
• The majority found that the regime was a rational and coherent scheme for providing access to justice, despite individual flaws.
• The dissenting judgment considered the system discriminatory, with certain defendants incurring disproportionate liabilities without objective justification.

cases.name: Coventry and others v Lawrence and another (No 2) [2014] UKSC 46
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellants, owners of Fenland bungalow, successfully claimed that respondents (occupiers of a stadium and track) were liable for nuisance due to noise interference from racing activities
• The trial judge issued an injunction against the respondents limiting noise from the stadium and track
• There were four issues: whether the injunction should be suspended until the premises are rebuilt;
• When the parties might able to vary the injunction;
• Whether the landlords were also liable;
• And if the order for costs infringed Article 6.

Issues
• The respondents claimed the landlords' liability for the nuisance should be dismissed as the landlords did not participate in the nuisance
• The Court decided to adjourn for further hearing after notice of consideration.

Decision
• The injunction should be suspended until Fenland is rebuilt;
• There should not be a delay before the parties are able to apply to vary the injunction;
• The landlords were not found liable as no factors established that they authorised or participated in the nuisance;
• The respondents' contention that the injunction contradicts their rights under Article 6 of the Convention would be infringing, and it may be claimed that any liability would be inconsistent with their Convention rights.

cases.name: Zurich Insurance PLC UK Branch v International Energy Group Limited [2015] UKSC 33
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr Carré was exposed to asbestos dust by his employer, 'GGLCL', for 27 years and later contracted mesothelioma.
• Carré sued the Respondent ('IEG'), as the successor in title of GGLCL, and recovered £250,000 damages and £15,300 in costs.
• IEG also incurred defence costs of £13,151.60.
• GGLCL had two insurance policies, one for 2 years and the other, 'Zurich', for 6 years.

Issues
• The Supreme Court had to decide whether the reasoning in Barker still applies in Guernsey, and if their decision would mean that an employer’s liability insurer covering an employer for only part of the period during which the employer exposed a victim is liable for only a pro rata part of the employer’s liability to the victim.
• If Barker does not apply, the Supreme Court had to determine whether such an insurer is liable in the first instance for the whole of the employer’s liability to the victim and if so, the Supreme Court needed to decide whether the insurer has pro rata rights to contribution from any other insurer of that employer and/or from the employer in respect of any periods not covered by the insurer.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously held that the common law rule of proportionate recovery established in Barker continues to apply in Guernsey.
• Zurich’s appeal in respect of compensation was allowed but dismissed in relation to defence costs.
• The majority of the Court concluded that Zurich would have been liable in the first instance to meet IEG’s claim in respect of their compensation but would have been entitled to pro rata contribution from Excess and IEG.

cases.name: Darnley v Croydon Health Services NHS Trust [2018] UKSC 50
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Michael Darnley, suffered a head injury and attended the Accident and Emergency (A&E) Department at Mayday Hospital, managed by the respondent, NHS Trust.
• The receptionist informed Darnley that he would have to wait up to four to five hours before he could be seen by a clinician.
• Darnley left the hospital after 19 minutes as he felt too unwell to remain, and subsequently suffered permanent brain damage.
• Darnley brought proceedings against the respondent, alleging a breach of duty by the reception staff.
• The High Court dismissed the claim, as did the Court of Appeal, but Darnley appealed to the Supreme Court.

Issues
• The Supreme Court had to determine whether the receptionist and the health trust owed a duty of care to Darnley, whether the damage was within the scope of any duty owed, and whether there was a causal link between any breach of duty and the injury.
• Darnley argued that such a duty of care was owed while the respondent claimed otherwise.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and remitted the case for assessment of damages.
• The court established that a duty of care was owed, covering a duty not to provide misleading information which may cause physical injury.
• The court also found that both the receptionist and the health trust owed the duty, regardless of their medical qualifications.
• Finally, the court established that providing misleading information on wait times constituted a negligent breach of duty, and that the appellant's departure based on that information did not break the chain of causation.

cases.name: BPE Solicitors and another (Respondents) v Hughes-Holland (in substitution for Gabriel) (Appellant) [2017] UKSC 21
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr Gabriel, a semi-retired businessman, entered into a transaction with his friend Mr Little to borrow £200,000 for the development of a disused heating tower
• Mr Gabriel instructed Mr Spencer, a solicitor at BPE Solicitors, to draw up a facility letter and a charge over the building for the transaction
• The transaction failed and Mr Gabriel lost all his money, leading him to sue BPE for negligence among other claims

Issues
• Mr Gabriel claimed full damages for the entire loss he suffered by entering the transaction, arguing that he would not have done so if he had not been misled
• BPE Solicitors argued that they were not responsible for all of Mr Gabriel's losses as their instructions were limited to drafting documentation for the transaction

Decision
• The Supreme Court dismissed Mr Gabriel's appeal unanimously
• Lord Sumption held that BPE Solicitors did not assume responsibility for Mr Gabriel's decision to lend money to Mr Little
• BPE was only legally responsible for confirming Mr Gabriel's assumption about one of a number of factors in his assessment of the project and his losses were attributed to his commercial misjudgements, which were not of BPE's concern

cases.name: The Catholic Child Welfare Society and others (Appellants) v Various Claimants and The Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools (Respondents) [2012] UKSC 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case concerns alleged acts of sexual and physical abuse of children by members of the Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools between 1952-1992 at St Williams, a residential institution for boys.
• The Institute did not own the school and had no direct contractual relationships with the brothers who taught there.
• Claims were brought by 170 men against both the managers of the school (the Middlesbrough Defendants) and members of the Institute (the Institute Defendants).
• The High Court and the Court of Appeal held that the Institute Defendants were not vicariously liable for the acts of abuse committed by the brothers at the School.
Issues
• The Middlesbrough Defendants appealed to the Supreme Court, arguing that the Institute Defendants should share vicarious liability for sexual abuse committed by the brothers.
• The Institute Defendants contended that the absence of a contractual relationship with the brothers meant that they could not be vicariously liable.
Decision
• The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, finding that it was fair, just, and reasonable for the Institute Defendants to share vicarious liability with the Middlesbrough Defendants.
• The Court held that the relationship between the Institute and the teaching brothers had all of the essential elements of that between employer and employee, and thus the first stage of the test for vicarious liability was satisfied.
• The Court also found the necessary close connection between the relationship and the wrongdoer was established, as the Institute's relationship with the abusers put it in a position to use them to carry on its business in a way that created or significantly enhanced the risk of abuse.

cases.name: Woodland (Appellant) v Essex County Council (Respondent) [2013] UKSC 66
cases.summary:
Facts
• On 5 July 2000, the appellant, a 10-year-old student, suffered a hypoxic brain injury during a school swimming lesson in Basildon, Essex
• The school had outsourced swimming lessons to Beryl Stopford (trading as Direct Swimming Services), who provided two employees for the lessons who allegedly failed to notice the appellant getting into difficulties in the water
• The appellant sued various parties for negligence, including the respondent (the education authority for the school)

Issues
• Appellant argued that the respondent owed her a 'non-delegable duty of care', meaning it was liable for any negligence on the part of the outsourced employees
• Respondent denied that it owed such a duty and applied to strike out that allegation against it; the allegation was struck out in High Court and upheld in the Court of Appeal

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal against the order striking out the allegation of a non-delegable duty
• The case will return to the High Court to determine whether the appellant was in fact a victim of negligence

cases.name: Armes v Nottinghamshire County Council [2017] UKSC 60
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant was in the respondent's care between the ages of seven and eighteen.
• She was placed into foster care and experienced abuse from her foster carers.
• The claim was based on the local authority being liable for the abuse, either due to breach of a non-delegable duty or on the grounds of vicarious liability.

Issues
• The appellant argued that the local authority was liable for the abuse she suffered.
• The local authority disputed this liability.
• The claim was dismissed by the High Court and the Court of Appeal.

Decision
• The Supreme Court allowed the appeal with a majority of 4-1, finding the local authority vicariously liable for the abuse committed by the foster parents.
• The court rejected the argument that the local authority was liable on the basis of a non-delegable duty.
• The judgment was based on the principles set out in Cox v Ministry of Justice [2016] UKSC 10.

cases.name: WM Morrison Supermarkets plc (Appellant) v Various Claimants (Respondents) [2020] UKSC 12
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant supermarket chain employed Andrew Skelton, who held a grievance against the company.
• Skelton leaked payroll data of the company’s entire workforce to a filesharing website and three newspapers.
• He was prosecuted and imprisoned.
• Some affected employees brought proceedings against the appellant on the basis of vicarious liability for Skelton’s illegal acts of breach of statutory duty, misuse of private information, and breach of confidence.
• The trial judge and the Court of Appeal found the appellant vicariously liable for Skelton’s actions.

Issues
• The main issue concerned whether the supermarket was vicariously liable for Skelton’s conduct under the 'close connection test'.
• The appellant argued that Skelton’s actions were not part of his 'field of activities'.
• The secondary issue questioned whether the Data Protection Act 1998 (DPA) excluded vicarious liability for both statutory and common law wrongs.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously reversed the decisions of the lower courts, holding that the appellant was not vicariously liable for Skelton’s conduct.
• Skelton's wrongful disclosure of data was not closely connected to his authorized task, and therefore, he was not acting within the ordinary course of his employment when committing the wrongful act.
• The Supreme Court also expressed its disagreement with the appellant’s argument that the DPA excluded the imposition of vicarious liability, but did not rely on this reasoning for its decision.

cases.name: Barclays Bank plc v Various Claimants [2020] UKSC 13
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimants alleged that between 1968 and 1984, they were sexually assaulted by Dr Gordon Bates during pre-employment medical examinations, which were part of Barclays Bank's recruitment procedures.
• Dr Bates, who has since died, was a self-employed medical practitioner and was paid a fee for each examination he conducted for Barclays.
• The claimants sought damages, and Barclays was held vicariously liable for Dr Bates' assaults by both the trial judge and the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• Barclays argued that since Dr Bates was an independent contractor and not an employee, it could not be held liable for his wrongdoing.
• The claimants contended that recent Supreme Court decisions had broadened the concept of vicarious liability to relationships beyond just employment and that it was 'fair, just, and reasonable' to hold Barclays liable.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Barclays' appeal, holding that the bank was neither vicariously liable nor responsible for Dr Bates' alleged sexual assaults.
• Such liability only arises when the relationship between the defendant and the tortfeasor is employment or the relationship is 'sufficiently akin or analogous to employment.'
• The Court maintained the distinction between relationships akin to employment and relationships with independent contractors, finding that Dr Bates was an independent contractor and thus, Barclays was not vicariously liable.

cases.name: Campbell (Appellant) v Gordon (Respondent) (Scotland) [2016] UKSC 38
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr. Campbell, an apprentice joiner, was employed by a company whose sole director was Mr. Gordon
• Mr. Campbell suffered an injury while working with an electric saw, resulting from inadequate insurance coverage
• The company's failure to provide appropriate insurance was a breach of section 1(1) of the Employers' Liability (Compulsory Insurance) Act 1969 ('the 1969 Act')

Issues
• The main issue was whether Mr. Gordon, as the director of the company, was personally liable in damages to Mr. Campbell due to the inadequate insurance
• The Appellant's claim was upheld by the Lord Ordinary but dismissed by a majority of the Inner House.

Decision
• The Supreme Court dismissed Mr. Campbell’s appeal by a 3-2 majority, holding that there is no authority for a person to be made indirectly liable for a breach of an obligation imposed by statute on someone else
• The Court found that the imposition of criminal liability was insufficient to render the director civilly liable

cases.name: Hounga (Appellant) v Allen and another (Respondent) [2014] UKSC 47
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Miss Hounga, was brought to the UK by Mrs Allen. Her entry was achieved by her presentation of a false identity and visa. Miss Hounga had no right to work in the UK but was employed by Mrs Allen to take care of her children. Mrs Allen was physically abusive.
• In July 2008, Mrs Allen evicted Miss Hounga and dismissed her. This appeal states that Mrs Allen discriminated against Miss Hounga on racial grounds.

Issues
• The main legal issue was whether the illegality defense defeated the complaint of discrimination. The Court of Appeal held that the defense of illegality should succeed if there is an inextricable link between the complaint and the claimant's illegal conduct.
• The defense of illegality rests upon public policy and considerations of it are necessary.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allows the appeal in relation to Miss Hounga's claim for the statutory tort of discrimination, as there is an insufficiently close connection between her immigration offenses and her claim for the tort.
• The defense of illegality was not deemed applicable in this case.

cases.name: Jetivia SA and another (Appellants) v Bilta (UK) Limited and others (Respondents) [2015] UKSC 23
cases.summary:
Facts
• Bilta (UK) Ltd was wound up in 2009 after a claim that its directors and appellants, Jetivia SA and Jetivia's CEO, were parties to a fraudulent scheme.
• The appellants applied to strike out Bilta's claim on the basis of illegality and the argument that Section 213 of the Insolvency Act 1986 does not have extra-territorial effect.

Issues
• The issues related to the application of the illegality defense and the circumstances in which the knowledge of directors is attributed to a legal person.
• Appellants' primary argument was that Bilta's claims against its directors are barred by the criminal nature of the company's conduct.
• The Court also considered whether Section 213 of the Insolvency Act 1986 has extra-territorial effect.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal both in relation to the illegality defense and in relation to section 213.
• The Court held that the illegality defense cannot bar Bilta's claims against the appellants, as the conduct of the directors cannot be attributed to the company in the context of a claim against the directors for a breach of their duties.
• The Court also held that Section 213 of the Insolvency Act 1986 has extra-territorial effect, and therefore can be invoked against the appellants.

cases.name: Regency Villas Title Ltd and others v Diamond Resorts (Europe) Ltd and others [2018] UKSC 57
cases.summary:
Facts
• Broome Park is a country estate which was divided into various properties.
• Regency Villas Title Ltd (Respondents) acquired rights to use sporting and recreational facilities which were developed by Gulf Investments Ltd, owner of the Park.
• Facilities deteriorated, and the Park owner denied the Respondents' right to use them, resulting in disputes over payment for facility use.
• The Respondents claimed a declaration for an easement allowing free usage of the facilities.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the Facilities Grant amounted to an easement.
• The Respondents argued that the grant of recreational and sporting rights was an easement.
• The Park owner disputed the validity of this easement, arguing that the Respondents had no enforceable rights to the leisure complex.

Decision
• The Supreme Court majority dismissed the appeal, allowing the cross-appeal and restoring the trial judge's orders, which provided monetary compensation for the payment under protest for use of the facilities.
• The majority held that the grant of recreational rights over the land may amount to an easement if the well-settled conditions for easements are met.
• Lord Carnwath dissented, arguing that the Ellenborough Park principle should not extend to a full leisure complex, which would require an extension of the law on easements not supported by case law.

cases.name: Scott (Appellant) v Southern Pacific Mortgages Limited (Respondents) [2014] UKSC 52
cases.summary:
Facts
• This case arose from 'sale and rent back' transactions, where homeowners in financial difficulty sold their properties at an undervalue, remaining in occupation as tenants.
• The appellant, Mrs Scott, sold her home to a nominee purchaser of North East Property Buyers (NEPB), who obtained a mortgage from Southern Pacific Mortgages Ltd.
• Upon default by the purchaser, Southern Pacific brought possession proceedings.

Issues
• Mrs Scott argued that she had an equitable interest in the property from the moment of the exchange of contracts, giving her priority over the lender's charges under the Land Registration Act 2002.
• The courts below decided that she had no equitable interest, and the Supreme Court was asked to decide whether the appellant could rely on an equitable interest against Southern Pacific.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal, holding that Mrs Scott acquired no more than a personal right when she agreed to sell her house and could not rely on an equitable interest against the lender's charges.
• The justices disagreed on the application of the indivisible transaction concept from the case of Abbey National Building Society v Cann [1991] 1 AC 56, but it was not necessary to decide this point for the appeal.
• Lady Hale expressed unease with the 'all or nothing' approach of the present law and welcomed a wide-ranging review of the Land Registration Act 2002 by the Law Commission.

cases.name: Jones v Kernott [2011] UKSC 53
cases.summary:
Facts
• Ms. Jones and Mr. Kernott had purchased a house in joint names, with no express statement of how beneficial interests would be shared.
• The mortgage and upkeep of the house was shared by both parties until Mr. Kernott moved out in 1993.
• In 2006, Mr. Kernott sought to claim a beneficial share in the property, following which Ms. Jones applied for a declaration that she owned the entire beneficial interest.

Issues
• The county court judge held Mr. Kernott was entitled to a 10% share based on changes in the parties' common intention regarding ownership (relying upon Stack v Dowden), and that it had to infer or impute an intention for the parties regarding a fair division of the property.
• The Court of Appeal overturned the decision, siding with Mr. Kernott's arguments that it was incorrect to infer or impute any change in common intention or substitute a fair division.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously restored the county court's order, with differing routes and reasons offered.
• Lord Walker, Lady Hale, and Lord Collins agreed on the application of principles established in Stack v Dowden and found the county court judge’s decision correct based on logical inferences.
• Lord Kerr and Lord Wilson found it impossible to infer the parties' intentions and instead looked to a fair division, similar to that made by the county court judge.

cases.name: Berrisford (FC) (Appellant) v Mexfield Housing Co-operative Limited (Respondent) [2011] UKSC 52
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mexfield Housing Co-Operative Ltd was founded by a bank as a mortgage rescue scheme and acquired 17 Elton Avenue from Ms Ruza Berrisford, then let it back to her under an 'Occupancy Agreement'
• The Occupancy Agreement provided that rent was payable weekly in advance and could only be determined through certain specified arrangements
• Mexfield sought to end Ms Berrisford's occupation by serving a notice to quit but initially failed to get a summary judgment

Issues
• Mexfield argued that the Occupancy Agreement could not be a valid express tenancy due to uncertainty, and an implied periodic tenancy had arisen due to payment and acceptance of rent since the 1993 agreement
• The Court of Appeal agreed with Mexfield, deciding in favor of an order of possession

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal, ruling that the Occupancy Agreement took effect as a lease for 90 years, determinable by Mexfield only on one month's notice upon Ms Berrisford's death or in accordance with the provisions of clause 6 of the Occupancy Agreement
• Lord Neuberger gave the leading judgment, reaffirming the rule that an agreement for an uncertain duration could not give rise to a tenancy and concluding that Ms Berrisford's tenancy was not intended to be precarious
• The Occupancy Agreement was treated as a 90-year term according to the common law and section 149(6) of the Law of Property Act 1925

cases.name: Arnold (Respondent) v Britton and others (Appellants) [2015] UKSC 36
cases.summary:
Facts:
• Oxwich Leisure Park contained ninety-one chalets leased on a 99-year term from 25 December 1974.
• Clause 3(2) of each lease contains a covenant to pay a proportionate part of the service charge.
• The Respondent, the landlord, argued that the lessee should pay an initial annual service charge of £90, with a compound rate of 10% increase for the first 70 chalets, every three years, and for the last 21 chalets, every year.

Issues:
• The issue was whether the Respondent’s interpretation of clause 3(2) was correct.
• The Appellants argued that there was an implied term in the 21 leases requiring the lessor to ask the lessee for service charges similar to those of other chalets.

Decision:
• The Supreme Court held (4-1) that the Respondent's interpretation was correct and dismissed the appeal.
• The court emphasised that while commercial common sense was important, it should not undervalue the language of the provision.
• It was not the function of the court to relieve a party from the consequences of imprudence or poor advice.
• The court held that the implied term argued by the Appellants would be inconsistent with an express term of the leases.
• In his dissent, Lord Carnwath considered the commercial purpose of the clause was ambiguous and, taking into account commercial common sense, he would have allowed the appeal.

cases.name: Braganza v BP Shipping Limited and another [2015] UKSC 17
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr Braganza disappeared while working as a Chief Engineer on an oil tanker managed by BP.
• BP determined he committed suicide, thus his widow was denied death benefits.
• Mrs Braganza sued BP for death benefits, but both the High Court and Court of Appeal upheld BP's determination.

Issues
• The court had to decide whether BP was entitled to form the opinion that Mr Braganza committed suicide.
• Mrs Braganza argued that Mr Sullivan failed to consider the inherent improbability of suicide and the real possibility of an accident.
• BP argued that their conclusion of suicide was reasonable according to the evidence.

Decision
• The Supreme Court allowed Mrs Braganza's appeal by a majority of 3 to 2.
• The court held that a decision that an employee has committed suicide is not rational or reasonable unless the employer has had it clearly in mind that suicide is such an improbability that cogent evidence is required.
• The employer should have directed himself that cogent evidence was required sufficient to overcome the inherent improbability of suicide.
• The court found that Mr Sullivan's decision was unreasonable as it was formed without taking relevant matters into account.

cases.name: Bunge SA v Nidera BV [2015] UKSC 43
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Grain and Feed Trade Association's standard form of FOB (Free on Board) sale contract GAFTA Form 49 applied to a contract between Bunge SA (sellers) and Nidera BV (buyers) for the delivery of 25,000 tonnes of Russian milling wheat crop
• Russia's embargo of wheat exports resulted in the sellers declaring the contract cancelled under GAFTA 49’s Prohibition Clause
• The buyers treated the purported cancellation as a repudiation of the contract, which they accepted, and began arbitration proceedings under GAFTA rules

Issues
• The sellers disputes that they were in breach of contract
• The only issue between the parties concerns damages
• The GAFTA Appeal Board held that the buyers were entitled to a damages award of US$3,062,500
• The sellers’ appeal was dismissed by both Hamblen J and the Court of Appeal

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allows the appeal
• Claims that the GAFTA 49 Default Clause provides a complete code for determining the market price or value of the goods but does not deal with subsequent events which would have resulted in the original contract not being performed in any event
• Following The Golden Victory, the buyers in fact lost nothing and should receive only nominal damages in the sum of US$5
• Lord Toulson agrees with Lord Sumption and holds that the language of the Default Clause is not sufficiently clear to preclude the application of The Golden Victory

cases.name: Wells v Devani [2019] UKSC 4
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr Devani, an estate agent, claimed he was owed commission by Mr Wells, a property vendor.
• Both parties disagreed on the terms and existence of a contract regarding commission.
• Mr Devani found a buyer for Mr Wells' flats and claimed his commission.
• Lower courts disagreed on the existence of a binding contract.

Issues
• Mr Devani argued there was an enforceable agreement despite the absence of an express event triggering commission payment.
• Mr Wells submitted that Mr Devani's failure to comply with the Estate Agents Act 1979 discharged Mr Wells' liability.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Mr Devani's appeal and dismissed Mr Wells' cross-appeal.
• The court found a binding contract existed and that payment was due upon completion, with the proceeds of the sale.
• Mr Devani's failure to comply with obligations under the Estate Agents Act did not justify dismissing his claim, as his non-compliance was minor.

cases.name: Tillman v Egon Zehnder Ltd [2019] UKSC 32
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 2003, Egon Zehnder Ltd. hired Mary Tillman and she eventually rose to joint global practice head in 2012.
• Her contract contained a non-competition covenant with a duration of 6 months from termination, preventing her from engaging or being 'concerned or interested' in competing businesses.
• After her employment ended, Ms Tillman informed the company she would be joining a competitor and claimed the non-competition covenant was in unreasonable restraint of trade and thus void.
• Egon Zehnder Ltd. sought an interim injunction to prevent her from joining the competitor.

Issues
• On appeal to the Supreme Court, three issues were considered: the scope of application of the restraint of trade doctrine, whether 'interested in' prohibited shareholding, and whether the correct severance approach was applied.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal. It found that the restraint of trade doctrine applied to the case.
• The words 'interested in' were found to prohibit shareholding and thus, the non-competition covenant was void due to unreasonable restraint of trade.
• The Beckett approach to severance was applied, and the prohibition against being 'interested in' was removed. The remaining restraints were upheld, and the injunction sought by Egon Zehnder Ltd. was formally restored.

cases.name: Harcus Sinclair LLP and another v Your Lawyers Ltd [2021] UKSC 32
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Harcus Sinclair LLP and another v Your Lawyers Ltd, the case revolved around a non-compete clause in a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) between two law firms, barring one firm from participating in emissions litigation without the other firm's permission.
• An informal collaboration began between the firms, but Harcus Sinclair later pursued its group action and partnered with another law firm, breaching the non-compete clause according to Your Lawyers.

Issues
• The decisive factors were whether the non-compete clause was (i) enforceable as a reasonable restraint of trade and (ii) a solicitor's undertaking.
• Your Lawyers argued that the non-compete clause protected their legitimate interests and was a solicitor's undertaking.
• Harcus Sinclair contended that the clause was an unreasonable restraint of trade and not a solicitor's undertaking.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the non-compete clause was enforceable as it was a reasonable restraint of trade, sufficiently protecting Your Lawyer's legitimate interests without being contrary to the public interest.
• The Court found that the non-compete clause was not a solicitor's undertaking as it did not involve the sort of work typically carried out by solicitors in their professional capacity, and the Court declined to extend its supervisory jurisdiction to cover LLPs or limited companies providing legal services.
• As a result, the Supreme Court allowed Your Lawyer's appeal, rendering the non-compete clause enforceable.

cases.name: Lloyds TSB Foundation for Scotland v Lloyds Banking Group Plc [2013] UKSC 3
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1986, Lloyds Banking Group Plc (Appellant) executed a Deed to provide four charitable foundations with payments totaling 1% of the its pre-tax profits. The Lloyds TSB Foundation for Scotland (Respondent) was one of them. The Deed was executed in 1986, amended in 1993, and replaced in 1997.
• Pre-Tax Profits were defined as the 'group profit before taxation' or 'group loss before taxation' shown in the Audited Accounts. The Deed was to be understood in the original legal and accounting context, where realized profits were included in the profit and loss account.
• Following the acquisition of HBOS in 2009, the Appellant's Audited Accounts included a 'gain on acquisition' of over £11 billion. The Respondent claimed this constituted the group profit, entitling them to a payment of £3,543,333, while the Appellant argued that 'gain on acquisition' should be disregarded, entitling the Respondent to only £38,920.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the 'gain on acquisition' should be included in the pre-tax profits when calculating the payments due to the Respondent under the Deed. The Appellant contended that it should be excluded as it was unthinkable at the time the Deed was made, while the Respondent argued the opposite.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and restored the Lord Ordinary’s decree of absolvitor, dismissing the claim.
• They reasoned that the Deed should be understood in the original legal and accounting context when realized profits were included in the profit and loss account. The Respondent should not derive any benefit from an unrealized gain that it could not derive from a realized profit.
• The Court did not equitably adjust the contract as while the performance was no longer as originally contemplated, it was not impossible or destroyed.

cases.name: Manchester Building Society (Appellant) v Grant Thornton UK LLP (Respondent) [2021] UKSC 20
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Manchester Building Society, obtained negligent advice from the respondent, Grant Thornton UK LLP, on the use of 'hedge accounting' for its financial statements.
• The society followed this advice, entering into long-term interest rate swaps to hedge its lifetime mortgages business, before discovering the error and incurring £32m to exit the swaps.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the society could recover the £32m cost from Grant Thornton, based on the scope of duty principle demonstrated in South Australia Asset Management Corpn v York Montague Ltd [1997] AC 191 ('SAAMCO').
• Both the trial judge and Court of Appeal denied the society's claim, prompting their appeal to the Supreme Court.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal, holding that the society's loss fell within the scope of the duty of care assumed by Grant Thornton.
• The court determined that damages should be reduced by 50% due to contributory negligence.

cases.name: Marks and Spencer plc v BNP Paribas Services Trust Company (Jersey) Limited [2015] UKSC 72
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 2006, BNP granted to Marks & Spencer (M&S) sub-underleases of floors in a building known as The Point in Paddington Basin, London.
• Clause 8 entitled M&S to determine the Lease on 24 January 2012 by giving BNP six months’ prior written notice (a “break notice”).
• On 7 July 2011, M&S served a break notice on BNP and paid the basic rent and break payment, among other payments.
• M&S subsequently brought a claim for the return of the apportioned basic rent after the lease was determined, contending that there should be an implied term in the Lease that allowed for a refund of the proportion of basic rent paid from the determination date up to and including 24 March 2012.

Issues
• The principal issue is whether the Lease should be interpreted to include an implied term that allows for a refund of the proportion of basic rent paid from the determination date up to and including 24 March 2012.
• M&S argued based on the test for the implication of contractual terms that such a term should be implied to give effect to the perceived commercial common sense of the Lease.
• BNP argued against implying such a term, relying on the Apportionment Act 1870 and long-standing common law which do not apportion rent payable in advance.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed M&S’s appeal.
• The Court upheld the current test for the implication of contractual terms and ruled that it is not necessary to imply the term to make the Lease commercially workable.
• The Court held that the Apportionment Act 1870 and long-standing common law make it clear that rent payable in advance is not apportionable, thus it would be inappropriate to imply a term suggesting otherwise.

cases.name: Morris-Garner and another (Appellants) v One Step (Support) Ltd (Respondent) [2018] UKSC 20
keywords: Thomas Wrotham Park Estate Co Ltd v Parkside Homes Ltd
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellants, former shareholders of One Step (Support) Ltd ('One Step'), were found to have breached restrictive covenants prohibiting competition and solicitation of clients
• The trial judge awarded damages to be assessed 'on a Wrotham Park basis'; that is, a hypothetical negotiated sum between the parties
• The Court of Appeal upheld the trial judge's decision

Issues
• The appellants argued that such negotiating damages were an incorrect measure of damages
• One Step sought to uphold the trial judge's decision

Decision
• The Supreme Court allowed the appeal on the basis of an incorrect approach to the assessment of damages
• It considered negotiating damages to be potentially available only where the claimant has suffered the loss of a valuable asset due to the breach
• The case was remitted to the High Court to measure One Step's actual financial loss

cases.name: Rainy Sky S.A. and others v Kookmin Bank [2011] UKSC 50
cases.summary:
Facts
• This case concerns six shipbuilding contracts, where the Buyers entered into contracts with Jinse Shipbuilding Co Ltd ('the Builder').• The Builder experienced financial difficulties and became subject to a formal debt workout procedure.• The Buyers demanded repayment under the Bonds from the Respondent bank, which were issued in relation to the shipbuilding contracts, but the Respondent rejected the Buyers' demands.

Issues
• The main issue is whether the Buyers were entitled to payment from the Respondent regarding the refunds under the Bonds.• The Buyers argued that the phrase 'such sums' in paragraph 3 of the Bonds referred to all pre-delivery instalments paid by the Buyers.• The Respondent argued that the expression 'such sums' in paragraph 3 of the Bonds was limited to the sums referred to in paragraph 2, which did not include any reference to the Buyers' rights under Article XII.3 of the Contracts.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and restored the order of the High Court.• The court held that since the language of paragraph 3 is capable of two meanings, considerations of commercial commonsense were used, which led the court to prefer the Buyers' construction because it was consistent with the commercial purpose of the Bonds, whereas the Respondent's construction was not.

cases.name: RTS Flexible Systems Limited (Respondents) v Molkerei Alois Müller GmBH & Co (Appellants) [2010] UKSC 14
cases.summary:
Facts
• RTS and Müller began working together on a re-packaging process after signing a letter of intent, but they never entered into a formal written contract.
• A dispute arose related to the delivery of equipment by RTS to Müller.

Issues
• The question before the Supreme Court was if the parties entered into a contract after the expiry of the letter of intent, and if so, on what terms.
• The High Court held there was a contract based on limited terms, but not including Müller's standard contract conditions (MF/1 conditions).
• The Court of Appeal overturned the decision, finding no contract existed after the letter's expiration.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and held that the parties indeed reached a legally binding agreement, which contained wider terms than the limited terms found by the High Court judge.
• The court declared that the parties reached a binding agreement on or about 25 August 2005 on the terms agreed on or before 5 July (as subsequently varied on 25 August), and that the agreement was not subject to contract.
• The court emphasized the importance of reaching an agreement on terms before beginning work.

cases.name: Lowick Rose LLP (in liquidation) (Appellant) v Swynson Ltd and another (Respondents) [2017] UKSC 32
cases.summary:
Facts
• This case concerns an unsuccessful 2006 management buyout of Evo Medical Solutions ('Evo') by Evo Medical Solutions Ltd ('EMSL')
• The buyout was funded by a £15m interest-bearing loan to EMSL by Swynson Ltd, owned by Mr Hunt
• Swynson instructed accountancy firm Lowick Rose LLP to carry out due diligence on Evo; they negligently failed to draw attention to fundamental problems with Evo's finances
• In 2007, Evo was at risk of financial collapse and by December 2008, the 2006 loan was refinanced through a short-term non-interest bearing loan of £18.663m to EMSL by Mr Hunt.

Issues
• Swynson and Mr Hunt sought to recover damages for losses resulting from the buyout and all three loans
• Lowick Rose LLP argued that they had no liability for damages as Swynson suffered no loss, since the whole of the original loan was repaid in December 2008
• The Court of Appeal upheld the judge's award of £15m damages to Swynson, as they held the refinancing to be res inter alios acta.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Lowick Rose LLP's appeal, finding that the refinancing payments couldn't be regarded as collateral.
• The transferred loss principle didn't apply as it wasn't part of the object of the engagement of Lowick Rose LLP or any other aspect of the 2006 transaction to benefit Mr Hunt
